bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Population trends were difficult to estimate given the small size of the population for this rare breeder, but the expert opinion is that there were fewer breeding birds in 2012 than in 1980. Trends in localised areas indicate a long term decline - e.g. County Wicklow the number of breeding pairs has fallen by an estimated 10% in the short term and up to 35% in the long term. Records of breeding and singing Wood Warbler in Ireland (1966-1986) were documented in Hutchinson (1989). Numbers recorded in the Republic varied year on year with records of at least one singing male in Co. Wicklow in most years and with up to 4-5 singing males nationally. Peak numbers of singing males in the Republic were recorded in 1980 (12 males) and 1986 (17 males). Records from Hillis (2003) indicate the species was a regular breeder in the 1990s with fewer annual records in subsequent Irish Rare Breeding Bird Reports. Hence the short and long term population trends indicate a decline with these trends categorised as moderate as they are based on expert opinion and incomplete quantitative data (IRBBP Reports).

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info:
Wood Warbler is a rare breeder with probable breeding records every year (for the period 1968-1986) as noted in Hutchinson (1989). Between 1992-2011 (IRBBP Reports) they were reported as 'possible breeders' in three separate counties (Co. Wicklow, Co. Mayo, Co. Kerry).
Comparison of breeding atlas data (confirmed, probable and possible records) indicates a decline in the short-term range from 17 10km squares in 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993) to ten 10km squares in 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). In the long term, since 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976), the number of relevant 10km squares increased by 67% i.e. from six 10km squares to ten 10km squares. The quality of these range trends has been categorised as moderate to reflect the likely underrecording of the species (Expert opinion).

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: As Redstart is such a rare and difficult species to survey ascribing both short- and long-term trends is challenging. Overall for the period 1970-1986, up to four pairs were breeding in any given year (Hutchinson 1989). In 1980, 1 pair bred in Glenveagh (Co. Donegal) with 4 males singing in Co. Wicklow. As a species which is likely to be underrecorded and with few records detailed in the Irish Rare Breeding Bird Reports (see various Hillis IRBBP Reports), expert opinion (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland) was used to categorise population trends in the short and long term. The quality of the trend data is categorised as poor to reflect the uncertainty (expert opinion) in the magnitude of the declines. The short term population trend is considered to be stable. The long term trend is also considered to be stable (1980-2012) but with fluctuations in total numbers of breeding pairs since 1980, with numbers in the mid 1990s (Hillis 2003) considered to be at their highest (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland).

bird_report.range_additional_info: The current species distribution map was generated using data on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11; there were no possible records available (Balmer et al. 2013). As this species is likely to be underrecorded by the Bird Atlas 2007-11, the quality of the atlas data for Redstart is considered to be moderate.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Given Redstart is likely to be a species which is underrecorded, the quality of the trend data for short and long term changes in breeding range magnitude are categorised as moderate. The number of 10km square proven (confirmed or probable) breeding records fell from a total of six in 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976), to four in 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993) to two in 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). Therefore in the short term the breeding range change indicates a 50% decline, with a 67% decline in the long term breeding range of the species.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Proven breeding (i.e. confirmed and probable records) was recorded in 12 10km squares in recent years (Balmer et al. 2013). Previous All-Ireland estimates (for 1988-90) of 150-250 pairs (Herbert 1991). Currently at least 50 pairs in the Republic (Expert opinion) with a Class 2 estimate of 50-100 pairs given (see Guidance document)

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Expert opinion - R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland; http://birdwatchireland.ie/ Herbert, I.J. (1991) The status and habitat of the Garden Warbler at Crom Estate, Co. Fermanagh, and a review of its status in Ireland. Irish Birds 4: 369-376. Tucker, G.M. & Heath, M.F. (1994) Birds in Europe: their conservation status. Cambridge, U.K. : BirdLife International (BirdLife Conservation Series No. 3).
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Hutchinson (1989) describes Garden Warblers as summer visitors to both the River Shannon and the Cavan lakes where they breed in small numbers and are sporadic nesters elsewhere. In 1968-72, they were recorded nesting at Lough Derg, Lough Ree and Lough Bofin on the Shannon and at lakes in counties Cavan and Monaghan along with proved or suspected breeding in counties Carlow, Cork, Donegal, Kerry, Leitrim, Louth, Meath, Tipperary, Waterford and Wexford. Previous All-Ireland population estimates of 150-250 pairs, with up to 100 pairs breeding in the Upper and Lower Lough Erne strongholds in Northern Ireland for 1988-90 have been documented (Herbert 1991). Hence, the national population for 1988-90 would have been no more than 50-150 pairs, which is broadly similar to the most recent estimate of 50-100 pairs (see Section 2.2). With no national population estimate for 1980, the Birds in Europe I (Tucker & Heath 1994) estimate of 150-250 pairs for the period 1970-1990 would indicate that the population has undergone a decline. However, it is probable that this estimate was based on All-Ireland figures (150-250 pairs) detailed in Herbert (1991) and therefore, the long term population trend (using estimates for the Republic only) is considered to be stable and this is also supported by expert opinion (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland). There is no accurate population estimate for 2000. The Birds in Europe II (BirdLife International 2004) estimate of the Garden Warbler population (330-400 pairs) is considered to be an overestimate (Expert opinion – R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland). Without more reliable data, it is not possible to report on the magnitude of the short term population trend, but it is likely that the short term population trend broadly reflects the overall breeding range trend for the same period. The breeding range trend is categorised as largely stable in the short and long term with 37 10km squares (with breeding records) in 1968-72, 42 in 1988-91 and 38 in 2007-11.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Generating short and long term breeding range trends using proven (confirmed and probable) records only gives a range decline in the short term of 29% and in the long term of 59%. However, confidence in these trend data is low. It is the considered expert opinion (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland) that these range trend figures do not reflect the actual trend and that the species breeding range is stable in the short and long term, particularly when all breeding records (including possibles) for the breeding atlases 1962-72 (N=37), 1988-91 (N=42) and 2007-11 (N=38) are taken into account. Hence the short and long term trends given above are broadly based on all breeding 10km square records from the breeding atlases (Sharrock 1976; Gibbons et al. 1993; Balmer et al. 2013). The quality of these trends has been categorised as good as these trends are considered to be accurate to within 10%.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Usually a maximum of two pairs proven breeding in any year (1992-2001). It is difficult to estimate numbers and to prove breeding for this species (Hillis 2003). County Kildare and the Shannon Callows are strongholds. The best years were 1994 and 1995 when 27 and 28 calling males were estimated as present (Hillis 2003). For the breeding atlas period of 1988-91, Hillis (2003) uses a figure taken from Hutchinson (1989) of 20 breeding pairs as the population estimate for that period. With the current population estimated at being no more than 20 pairs, the population trend figures in the short and long term for this rare breeder are given as stable and the quality of the trend information has been categorised as poor.

bird_report.range_additional_info: Given the species is difficult to survey and to confirm breeding, the quality of the distribution and range maps is considered moderate as it may be that species is underrecorded to an extent. The current species distribution map shows the confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013).

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Given the species is difficult to survey and to confirm breeding (Hillis 2003), and therefore likely to be underrecorded, the trend data is considered to be of moderate quality. All proven breeding records (probable or confirmed) were pooled before comparison of percentage changes in numbers of 10km square records between bird atlases. However as a rare breeder, the total number of records for breeding Quail is small with an increase in the short term breeding range in proven 10km square records from four in 1988-91 to eight in 2007-11 indicating a maximum increase of 100%. In the long term the breeding range trend indicates a decline of 62% from 21 10km squares with proven records in the 1968-72 breeding atlas (Sharrock 1976) to eight 10km squares in the 2007-11 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al. 1993). The quality of the breeding range change data has been categorised as moderate as it may be that species is underrecorded to an extent.
bird_report.measures_taken: Quail is not legally hunted in Ireland and only breeds here in small numbers. Numbers are monitored through the Irish Rare Breeding Birds Panel reports (e.g. Hillis 2012) and periodically though Bird Atlas initiatives (see Balmer et al 2013).

(2011) Management prescriptions for twite in Ireland. Irish Wildlife Manuals, No. 52. McLoughlin, D.T. & Cotton, D. (2008) The status of Twite Carduelis flavirostris in Ireland 2008. Irish Birds, Vol 8, No 3, 323-334.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The breeding atlas of 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976) derived a British and Irish estimate of 20,000-40,000 pairs based on densities of 25-50 pairs per 10km square occupied. Given that there were 115 10km squares in which Twite were recorded in the Republic in 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976), an approximate estimate of 4,312 pairs (Range 2,875-5,750 pairs) was derived using the density figures provided. In the 1988-91 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al. 1993), the All-Ireland population was estimated at 3,500 pairs across 60 10km squares. As 52 of these 10km squares occurred in the Republic, a national estimate of 3,033 pairs was derived from the original All-Ireland figure. These historic bird atlas survey estimates were used for comparison purposes with the most recent information on Twite numbers (McLoughlin & Cotton 2008) to derive short term and long term trends. The quality of these population trend data has been categorised as moderate given the historical population estimates for 1968-72 and 1988-91 were derived based on assumptions of average densities of pairs per 10km square and were not derived using a complete survey.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short term and long term breeding range trends given are the percentage changes in the numbers of confirmed or probable 10km square records across the breeding atlases. The short term trend was based on a decline from 27 10km squares in 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993) to 14 10km square records in 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). The long term trend highlights the decline from a total of 78 10km squares with confirmed breeding records in 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976) to 14 10km squares in 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). Most losses have occurred in its former and once more extensive breeding range along the western seaboard counties (Sharrock 1976), with no proven records for eastern and southern counties recorded in the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al. 2013). The recent 2008 Twite study (Mc Loughlin & Cotton 2008) had a more restricted distribution in terms of survey effort than the breeding atlases, with a focus on known historic sites where Twite had previously bred in the west and northwest of the country.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The current national population estimate for Ring Ouzel (14-24 pairs) was derived by combining the results of the Upland Bird Survey 2002-03 (Cox et al. 2002; Cummins et al. 2003) in the northwest and west of Ireland with more recent data for counties Kerry (See 3.2.6 Sources - Allan Mee) and Wicklow (Hillis 2010; Hillis 2009). This estimate of 14-24 breeding pairs was compared with estimates taken from Birds in Europe I (Tucker & Heath 1994) and Birds in Europe II (BirdLife International 2004) to derive short term and long term population trends. The minimum estimates of 150 pairs (Birds in Europe I) and 50 pairs (Birds in Europe II) were compared with the most recent estimate of 14-24 pairs (2002-11) to derive long term and short term population trends. The minimum estimates from Birds in Europe I and II were chosen for comparative purposes as these were considered to be the most representative of Ring Ouzel populations circa 1980 and 2000 respectively, based on expert opinion (S. Cummins, BirdWatch Ireland).

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short term breeding range trend was derived from the percentage change in the total numbers of probable and confirmed breeding 10km square records between the breeding atlases of 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993). The number of 10km squares with proven records of breeding Ring Ouzel fell from 14 10km squares to 8 10km squares, a decline of 43% in the short term. Please note the Upland Bird Survey 2002-03 (Cox et al. 2002; Cummins et al. 2003) had a more restricted distribution in terms of survey area than the breeding atlases and was therefore not used to derive short term breeding range changes. For long term breeding range changes, differences in the total numbers of proven breeding records, with 21 10km squares in the 1968-72 breeding atlas (Sharrock 1976) and 8 10km squares in the 2007-11 breeding atlas (Balmer et al. 2013), were used to provide the long term trend figure of 62% decline. These trend estimates are the best available information but given the difficulties in detection of the species and proof of breeding they have been categorised as moderate in quality.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Short-term trend: Using the midpoint value (75 pairs) of the current population estimate with the midpoint value provided in Birds in Europe II (60 pairs) (BirdLife International, 2004), the trend indicates an increase of 16.7% in the short term. Long term trend: In Birds in Europe I (Tucker & Heath 1994), the population was estimated at 70 breeding pairs. With the current population estimated at 50-100 pairs (midpoint figure of 75 pairs), the long term population trend indicates the population is stable to increasing, with a maximum increase of 7%. Given these population estimates are largely anecdotal with little quantitative information available, the quality of the trend information has been categorised as poor.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Estimate is based on the current nest finding study in the stronghold for the species in Co. Wicklow. Records from elsewhere have been verified by experts (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland).

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Expert opinion - R. Coombes (BirdWatch Ireland)
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: This species was first proven to breed on the island of Ireland in 2006 and in the Republic in 2009. As the species is a recent colonist a long term trend cannot be provided. The short-term trend reflects this colonisation and expansion from seven confirmed nests in 2009 to 19 confirmed nests in 2012, with a further 15 territories held (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland). Using all possible records for 2012, the population has increased by 386% since 2009. The trend data has been categorised as moderate in quality as it is derived from the nest-finding study in the Co. Wicklow Great Spotted Woodpecker stronghold and it is likely that more than 10% of possible breeding records are not detected (expert opinion - R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland). Given Co. Wicklow holds the majority of breeding birds, the population trends there are considered to reflect the national trend.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Expert opinion - R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland. Http://birdwatchireland.ie/
bird_report.range_additional_info: Great Spotted Woodpecker is a recent coloniser with first proven breeding records for Ireland (IE) in 2009, with several individuals seen but with no evidence recorded of breeding in 2007 and 2008. The current species distribution map was generated using data on confirmed, probable and possible breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and on supplementary data from Dick Coombes. The recommended Range Tool determined the initial national range for this species but was modified by removing one 10km square (i.e. O00).

range_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.range_trend_sources: Expert opinion - R. Coombes (BirdWatch Ireland) using results from nest-finding study (unpublished). Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: In terms of its short term breeding range trend, it is known from the Co. Wicklow study that the species is expanding from confirmed or probable breeding in four 10km squares in 2009 to ten 10km squares in 2012 (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland), which is a 150% increase in breeding range. Hence the short term trend increase in breeding range is reflecting the expansion of this newly colonising species within its stronghold in County Wicklow and to neighbouring counties. Nationally, with proven breeding in a total of 17 10km squares during the period 2009-2012 (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland; Balmer et al 2013), a national increase of 325% was derived from the initial four 10km squares with breeding records in 2009. The breeding range short term trend data has been categorised as good in quality as records were taken from the breeding bird atlas of 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and supplemented by 2012 records (R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland) from the nest-finding study in Co. Wicklow. Therefore the range change is likely to be a reasonably accurate reflection of the current national trend. The long term trend is not populated as this species was not proven to breed until 2009.

population_method.desc: Estimate based on expert opinion with no or minimal sampling

Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B, & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Gadwall is thought to have colonised the island of Ireland naturally in the 1930s (Sharrock 1976) and breeding numbers for All-Ireland were estimated at less than ten pairs in the late 1970s, with an average of two breeding pairs recorded each year in the Republic during the period 1980-85 (see Hutchinson 1979). Since then, the species has undergone an increase in its breeding population in the long term. This increase (575%) was derived by using the midpoint of current estimates (14-23 pairs) to assess the long term change in the population since the early 1980s. The population is also showing an increase in the short term. The breeding atlas of 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993) estimated 30 pairs All-Ireland. Given half of the confirmed 10km square records for Gadwall at this time were in Northern Ireland, a realistic estimate for the Republic for that period is 15 pairs. The most recent national estimate of 14 -23 pairs is based on records detailed in the Irish Rare Breeding Birds Panel Reports (see Hillis reports 2007 - 2012) and the number of 10km squares (n=23) with probable or confirmed breeding records from the recent breeding bird atlas (Balmer et al. 2013). These recent figures suggest the short term population trend is stable at the very least with the minimum numbers (14 pairs) recorded in the 2008-11 period similar to numbers (15 pairs) estimated in the past (Gibbons et al. 1993). Taking the midpoint of the current estimate (18.5 pairs) and comparing that with the estimate of 15 pairs for the 1988-91 period, indicates a potential increase of 23% in the short term. It is important to note, however, that it is likely that not all breeding records for Gadwall were reported to the Irish Rare Breeding Birds Panel and therefore while the short term population trend is indicating an increase, the magnitude of this increase is more difficult to determine. Given Gadwall is a rare breeder, and there is variation in year to year reporting of breeding numbers, the calculated population trends for both the short term and long term have a high level of uncertainty and therefore have been categorised as poor.

The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 7 10km squares) using the same criteria.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The 1968-72 breeding atlas recorded Goosander breeding in one 10km square in Co. Donegal (Sharrock 1976). The 1988-91 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al. 1993) recorded them breeding in one 10km square in Donegal, with one possible record for Co. Mayo. The 2007-11 breeding atlas (Balmer et al. 2013) recorded Goosander as breeding (confirmed) in two 10km squares, and probably breeding in another. The most recent data available refers to the 2011 breeding season. This figure was assessed against data from Hillis (2003) and indicates that both the short- and long-term population trends for Goosander are stable.

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: Goosander was recorded as a probable breeder in one 10km square and confirmed breeding in two 10km squares in Co. Wicklow (Balmer et al. 2013). This represents a range increase on 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993), when there was just a single unconfirmed breeding record in Co. Donegal. A nestbox provision scheme in Co. Wicklow is supporting a number of breeding pairs. However, Goosander remains a rare breeder with up tp five pairs breeding per year.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Goosander is a rare breeder and was recorded as confirmed or probable breeding in three 10km squares in the 2008-2011 period (Balmer et al. 2013). This represents an increase of 200% in range since the 1968-72 breeding atlas (Sharrock 1976). Goosander was recorded in the 1988-1991 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al. 1993) in one 10km square record, with a possible breeding record in another. Hence, in the short term, the proven breeding range has increased by 200% and by 50% overall (taking all breeding records into account). Given Goosander is a rare breeder, with just three 10km squares with breeding records in 2007-11, the quality of the range trends has been categorised as moderate.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Reed Warbler were first proven to have bred in 1981 (Hutchinson 1989) with reports of pairs breeding and singing males in southern and eastern counties in subsequent years. The current best estimate of the population of breeding Reed Warblers is 100 pairs (based on expert opinion of R. Coombes, BirdWatch Ireland and reported records to the Irish Rare Breeding Birds Panel (IRBBP). This estimate was compared with an estimate for the Republic of 55-95 pairs given by Smiddy & O'Mahony (1997) to derive a short term population trend. The national estimate (of 5 pairs proven breeding in 1981) given in Hutchinson (1989) was used along with the most recent population estimate to derive a long term population trend. These data are the best available information but are limited to submitted records to the IRBBP and therefore the trend figures given (Sections 3.1.3 & 3.2.3 Magnitude) are considered to be moderate in quality (as per Article 12 Guidance document) as they are not based on a comprehensive dataset.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short term breeding range change was calculated by comparing the number of 10km squares with probable and confirmed breeding records in 1988-91 (4 squares: Gibbons et al. 1993) with that for 2007-11 (21 squares; Balmer et al. 2013). The long term trend was calculated by taking 1981 as the base year (breeding in one 10km square; Hutchinson 1989). Given that Reed Warblers occur in a limited number of 10km squares (Balmer et al. 2013), the trend figures provided should be treated with caution. Hence the quality of the estimates has been classified as moderate.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Tucker, G.M. & Heath, M.F. (1994) Birds in Europe: their Conservation Status. Cambridge, U.K.: BirdLife International (BirdLife Conservation Series No. 3). Expert opinion - Alex Copland, BirdWatch Ireland. http://birdwatchireland.ie/
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The population trend directions for Tree Sparrows in the short term and long term have been categorised as increasing. Birds in Europe I (Tucker & Heath 1994) estimated 400-600 breeding pairs in the Republic, with Birds in Europe II (BirdLife International 2004) indicating an increase to 1,000-2,499 pairs. The quality of these estimates, along with the most recent (given in Section 2.2), are considered to be moderate as they were derived largely using anecdotal evidence or expert opinion (A. Copland, BirdWatch Ireland). However, they do indicate an increase in the short term. Using the mid-point population figures for the period 2000-2012, numbers rose from 1,750 pairs to 2,000 pairs (an increase of 14%). In the longer term, the population has increased from a midpoint of 500 pairs (an increase of 300%). These magnitude values indicate increases in the short and long term population trends, but are considered to be moderate in quality as they are based on expert opinion with incomplete quantitative data. This species has undergone a significant increase in its breeding range (Section 5). Informed by this it is likely that the breeding population has also increased in line with the breeding range trend.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Short term range change was calculated looking at the most recent data available, i.e. 2008-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the 1988-91 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al. 1993). All breeding records (confirmed/probable/possible) were used to calculate percentage change figures. Long term breeding range change was calculated using data extracted from the 2007-11 breeding atlas (Balmer et al. 2013) and the 1968-72 breeding atlas (Sharrock 1976) using the same criteria. In the short term, the range trend is increasing, with numbers of 10km squares with breeding records increasing from 82 in 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993) to 142 in 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). Long term, the range trend is also indicating an increase from 88 10km squares in 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976) to 142 10km squares with breeding records in 2008-11 (Balmer et al. 2013), an increase of 61%.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
Short-term trend: As per the population estimate the short term population trend is primarily based on the reported number of occupied 10km squares (332) as reported in Gibbons et al (1993). The 1990’s population was calculated using the same density range as outlined in Gibbons (1993) and the midpoint of each range were compared to derive the percentage increase.
Long-term trend: As per the population estimate the short term population trend is primarily based on the reported number of occupied 10km squares (505) as reported in Sharrock (1976). The 1970’s population was calculated using the same density range as outline in Gibbons (1993) and the midpoint of each range were compared to derive the percentage decrease. The contrast between the long term decrease compared to the short term increase may be partly explained by poorer coverage of this species in Ireland during the 1988-91 Atlas thereby resulting in an overestimate of the short term trend. This potential difference in survey coverage/effort is reflected in the quality scores assigned to the two estimated trends.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short term range change was calculated by comparing the most recent data available i.e. 2007-11 breeding atlas (Balmer et al. 2013) and the 1988-91 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al. 1993). All breeding records (confirmed, probable and possible) were used to calculate percentage change figures (i.e. 406 10km squares vs. 332 10 km squares respectively). The long term range change was calculated by comparing the most recent data available i.e. 2007-11 breeding atlas (Balmer et al. 2013) and the 1968-72 breeding atlas (Sharrock 1976). All breeding records (confirmed, probable and possible) were used to calculate percentage change figures (i.e. 406 10km squares vs. 505 10 km squares respectively). The contrast between the long term decrease compared to the short term increase may be partly explained by poorer coverage of this species in Ireland during the 1988-91 Atlas thereby resulting in an overestimate of the short term trend. This potential difference in survey coverage/effort is reflected in the quality scores assigned to the two estimated trends.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Expert opinion - A. Copland, BirdWatch Ireland; http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser. Tucker, G.M. & Heath, M.F. (1994) Birds in Europe: their Conservation Status. Cambridge, U.K.: BirdLife International (BirdLife Conservation Series No. 3).
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The current breeding (2008-2011) Whinchat population is estimated to be 150-250 pairs in 37 10km squares (section 4). The all-Ireland population in 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993) was estimated at 1,250-2,500 pairs in 124 10km squares. This equates to an estimate of 988-1975 pairs in the Republic in 98 10km squares. Using the midpoints of these ranges the short term population trend of - 87% is calculated. Taking the lowest density estimate in Sharrock (1976) of 6 pairs per 10km square produces an estimated population of at least 1000 pairs in 161 10km squares. Birds in Europe I (Tucker & Heath 1994), estimated the population at 1,000 -2,000 pairs. Using the midpoint of this range as the historic population size in 1980 an 87% decline in the breeding population of Whinchat is estimated.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
Short-term trend: The Countryside Bird Survey (CBS) monitors the population of Ireland’s common countryside birds. This species is recorded as part of the survey but not in a regular and wide scale fashion in order to produce robust population trends. The total population is heavily influenced by feral birds in towns and cities where the CBS is not undertaken. Nevertheless the available CBS data does indicate a stable population.
Long-term trend: Over the long term period (i.e. 1968-72 to 2008 – 2011) the breeding range for this species has expanded and as this primarily informs the population size and trend assessment, a positive trend is assessed. In the absence of reliable bird census data, the magnitude of the population increase is assumed to be broadly similar to that of the range expansion

However insufficient data exists to quantify the magnitudes of these increasing trends with any degree of confidence. Therefore both the short- and the long-term trends have to be reported as 'unknown'.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The breeding range change trend figures in Section 5 indicates that the population has undergone an increase of 12% in breeding range (Balmer et al. 2013) since 1991 (Gibbons et al. 1993) and is stable in the long term, i.e. since 1972 (Sharrock 1976). Based largely on the range change data the population trend direction for 3.1.2 above gives an increase in the short term trend (2000-2011), with the population considered stable in the longer term (1980-2011). The quality of these trends is considered to be moderate as they are based primarily on range data and expert opinion as opposed to population survey data. Additionally the magnitude of the short term increase is likley not to exceed 50% of the BiE2 population estimate.

bird_report.population_sources: Crowe, O. & Holt, C. (2013) Estimates of waterbird numbers wintering in Ireland, 2006/07 – 2010/11. Irish Birds (unpublished).
bird_report.population_additional_info: No nationwide breeding swan survey has been conducted in recent years. However Mute Swans on the island of Ireland are largely sedentary and therefore the population estimate of 7120 individual swans counted during the winter months and reported as a five-year mean for the period 2006/07 to 2010/11 (Crowe & Holt 2013), is likely to be representative of this resident population. Cognisant of not accounting for non-breeding birds a tentative population estimate of up to 3560 pairs is arrived at by diving the number of individuals by two.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: I-WeBS unpublished data 1999-2011 - O. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland http://birdwatchireland.ie/.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Ogilvie, M.A. (1972) Distribution, numbers and migration. Pp 29-55 in Scott, P. and the Wildfowl Trust. The Swans. London. Sheppard, R. (1993) Ireland's Wetland Wealth. Irish Wildbird Conservancy. Crowe, O. & Holt, C. (2013) Estimates of waterbird numbers wintering in Ireland, 2006/07 – 2010/11. Irish Birds (unpublished).
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
The short-term population trend is based on data collected during the overwinter period as part of the Irish Wetland Bird Survey (I-WeBS). Using such data to estimate breeding population change is justified due to the fact that Mute Swan in Ireland is a resident species with no (or very few) individuals migrating here to overwinter. Although a 3% increase was calculated the overall short-term trend is considered to be stable.
I-WeBS did not commence until 1994 but prior to this Ogilvie (1972) estimated the All-Ireland population to be 5,000-6,000 birds in the early 1970s. Subsequently, Sheppard (1993) estimated the All-Ireland population at 10,000 individuals in the mid 1980s (1984-1987). Assuming that the relative percentages of swans occurring in Northern Ireland and in the Republic as estimated by Crowe and Holt (2013) were broadly similar to the situation in the mid-1980s an estimated 7,756 birds for the period 1984-1987 for the Republic can be generated. Although a 8% decrease was calculated the overall long-term trend is considered to be stable.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: The current species distribution and range map was generated using relevant data on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). This amounted to a total of 471 10km squares. A further 51 10km squares that held possible breeding records for this species are not presented here (see Balmer 2013).

The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 548 10km squares) using the same criteria.

British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Gibbons et al (1991) estimated the all-Ireland breeding population at 1,100 pairs.Using the proportion of the occupied squares in the Republic compared to those exclusively occurring in Northern Ireland a scaled population estimate of 872 breeding pairs in 1991 for the Republic is calculated. Relying on the range increase data sourced from the recent Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) and assuming that the breeding density has remained unchanged since 1991 then a contemporary population of 958 breeding pairs is estimated. As all records (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) were used in this analysis the presence of non-breeding immature birds in suitable breeding habitat may obscure, to some degree, the abundance of the true breeding population.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on expert opinion with no or minimal sampling

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short term trend is taken as the difference between the population estimates in Gibbons et al (1993) and Balmer et al (2013) as calculated in 2.8. This trend should be treated with caution. Primarily on account of the recorded increase in breeding range (section 5, Sharrock 1976, Balmer et al 2013) it is considered that the long-term population may well be increasing. However due to an insufficiency of data the magnitude of the increase is not reported here and therefore the long-term population has to be described as ‘unknown’.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Hutchinson, C.D. (1989) Birds in Ireland. Irish Wildbird Conservancy. T & A D Poyser.
bird_report.range_additional_info:
All relevant 10km square records with confirmed or probable breeding of Shelduck taken from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013), were used to generate the distribution and range maps. Shelduck usually do not breed until they are two years old and this leads to the presence of non-breeders occurring on estuaries during summer (Hutchinson 1989). Therefore only 10km squares with confirmed or probable breeding records were included here (162 10km squares in total).
This breeding species is primarily associated with coastal habitats. The Range Tool was used to define the initial range but all those inland 10km range squares that were not directly associated with a breeding record and did not intersect the coast were removed from the final range.

range_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 171 10km squares) using the same criteria. As all records (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) were used in the range trend analyses the presence of non-breeding immature birds in suitable breeding habitat may obscure the true breeding range trends.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Gibbons et al (1991) estimated the all-Ireland breeding population in Ireland at 75,000 breeding pairs. Using the proportion of occupied records occurring in the Republic compared to those exclusively occurring in Northern Ireland a scaled population estimate for 1991 is calculated to be 62,185 breeding pairs for the Republic. Relying on the relatively small range increase data sourced from the recent Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) and assuming that the breeding density has remained unchanged since 1991 then a contemporary population estimate of 64,496 breeding pairs is arrived at. This estimate is to be treated with caution primarily on account of the age of the density estimate

As such these population trend estimates should be treated with caution.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend is considered stable, but the long-term trend shows a decline. The species is widespread and the number of occupied 10km squares in the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013; 614 10km squares) and the previous 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993; 592) are broadly in agreement, so the short-term trend was assessed as stable. The long-term range trend was calculated from the baseline of the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 769 10km squares).

population_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Gibbons et al (1993) estimated the all-Ireland breeding population in Ireland at 8,600 individuals. Using the proportion of all occupied records occurring in the Republic compared to those exclusively occurring in Northern Ireland a scaled population estimate for 1991 is calculated to be 6,535 individuals for the Republic. Relying on the reported increase in range sourced from the recent Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) and assuming that the breeding density has remained unchanged since 1991 then a contemporary population estimate of 6,924 individuals is arrived at. This estimate is tentatively divided by two to produce an estimate of the numbers of pairs in the population. This estimate is to be treated with caution primarily on account of the age and robustness of the density estimate.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser, London.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: As the contemporary population estimate is primarily derived from the 1991 population estimate set out in Gibbons et al (1993) and the number of occupied 10km squares recorded during the 2007-11 Bird Atlas, both the long- and the short-term population trend estimates are informed by the respective range trend estimates (section 5). Although the short term range trend records an increase it is considered more prudent to describe the short-term trend as being broadly stable over the prescribed period. Over the long-term a significant decline in the breeding range has been recorded but due to an insufficiency of population survey data the magnitude of this trend is not reported here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as ‘unknown’.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
The short-term trend measured by the change in range between Gibbons et al (1993) and Balmer et al (2013) has been an increase but given the uncertainties of the population and range data (see section 5.3), the magnitude has not been reported. Therefore this trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.
The long-term trend measured by the change in range between Sharrock (1976) and Balmer et al (2013) has been a decline but given the uncertainties of the population survey data, the magnitude has not been reported. Therefore this trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 171 10km squares) using the same criteria. The short-term trend was assigned a quality score of 2 due the fact that the severity of the decrease in range recorded between the first and the second atlas could not be easily explained especially in light of other surveys indicating conflicting results (see Gibbons et al 1993).

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
Short-term population trend Gibbons et al estimated 2,500 pairs breeding on the island of Ireland. It is estimated that 2,133 of these occurred in the Republic. On the assumption that breeding density has not changed significantly between the atlas periods it is estimated that a 14% decline in breeding has occurred.
Long-term population trend Between the first and most recent atlases (i.e. 1968-72 to 2007-2011) a 40% decline in the range was recorded (see section 4). The use of density values estimated from field surveys collected during the period 1988-91 and applying this to distribution data collected during the periods 1968-72 and 2008 -2011 to derive a population trend should be treated with caution and therefore a poor quality score is assigned to this trend.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The first record of breeding Little Egret (at least 12 pairs) was at a Grey Heron colony in the southeast of Ireland (Smiddy and Duffy 1997). Over time the breeding distribution and numbers rose (see Section 4 and Hillis 2010). Hillis (2003) notes that there were 45 pairs recorded as breeding in 2000. As the contemporary population estimate is dependant to some degree on expert opinion the magnitude of both these long- and short-term population trends must be treated with caution.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_additional_info: The current species distribution and range map was generated using relevant data on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). This amounted to a total of 56 10km squares. A further 62 10km squares that held possible breeding records for this species are not presented here (see Balmer 2013).

The magnitude of the short-term increasing trend is not reported here due to an insufficiency of data.

(1993). Ireland's Wetland Wealth. Irish Wildbird Conservancy.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Gibbons et al (1993) estimated the all-Ireland breeding population at 3,650 breeding pairs. Excluding the proportion of the population in Northern Ireland produces an estimate of 3,069 breeding pairs for the Republic for that period. Factoring in the small change in recorded range between Gibbons et al (1993) and Balmer et al (2013) and assuming that the breeding density has remained unchanged then a contemporary population estimate of 3,087 breeding pairs is produced. This estimate is to be treated with caution due to the assumptions made and the uncertainty over the basis for the original density estimates.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: As the contemporary population estimate is primarily derived from the population estimate set out in Gibbons et al (1993) and the number of occupied 10km squares recorded during the 2007-11 Bird Atlas both the long- and the short-term population trend estimates are informed by the respective range trend estimates (section 5). Due to the stability in the total number of occupied 10km squares between the 1968 – 72, the 1988-91 and the 2007 – 11 atlases and assuming that the overall breeding density has not changed to any appreciable extent it is then estimated that the Irish population has remained stable both over the prescribed long- and the short-term periods.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the number of relevant occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013; 669 10km squares) with those of the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993; 665 10km squares). Although an increase of 1% is calculated it is considered more appropriate to describe the trend as being stable. The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 670 10km squares) using the same criteria.

Census of Great Crested Grebes, summer 1975. Irish Bird Rep. 1975:38-43. Perry, K. (2000) The Ecology and Conservation of Great Crested Grebes Podiceps cristatus at Lough Neagh, Northern Ireland. PhD Thesis, University of Ulster
bird_report.population_additional_info: In 2004 the population was reported as 1,000 – 2,499 pairs (BirdLife International 2004). This marked an increase from the last national survey of Great Crested Grebes in Ireland (Preston 1976) which estimated a population of 758 pairs. Perry (2000) however considered this to be an underestimate of the true population (Perry 2000). Although the short term range has increased (section 5) it is considered that the 2004 BirdLife International population estimate remains appropriate for this reporting period.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
Even though the short-term range has recorded an increase (section 5) it is likely that the population remains within the banded population estimate originally reported by BirdLife (2004) and used here as the contemporary population estimate. Therefore the population trend is reported here as being broadly stable.
Using Preston’s (1976) estimate an increasing long-term trend of 32 – 230% can be calculated but this estimate may have underestimated the true population (see Perry 2000). Due to this uncertainty and the lack of contemporary survey data no magnitude for this long-term population increase is given. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend was informed by data collected during two Common Scoter surveys which suggests a 62% decline occurred in Red-breasted Merganser abundance on a selection of loughs (Conn, Cullin, Cara, Corrib and Ree) between 1995 and 2012 (see Gittings 1995 and Hunt et al 2013). As this species was not the primary target of the surveys and due to the fact that other important areas for this species were not covered, this trend is indicative only of the direction in the national trend and should be treated with caution. Acknowledging the long-term decline in breeding range it can be considered that a population decline also occurred during this period. However due to a lack of population data the magnitude of this decline is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term trend has to be reported as ‘unknown’.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The population estimate is calculated from the current number of occupied 10km squares as per Balmer et al (2013; 202 10 km squares) and the density suggested by Sharrock (1976; 3-4 pairs per 10km square). This estimate should be treated with caution. As the long-term population trend is primarily informed by the long-term range trend which shows a 22% decrease (section 5) so a decreasing population trend is expected. However due to the uncertainty of the estimates over time a robust estimation of the magnitude is not possible. Therefore the long-term population trend is reported as ‘unknown’. On foot of the short-term range trend assessment the short term population trend is estimated to be stable.

The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the number of relevant occupied 10km squares from the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013; 202 10km squares) with those from the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993; 181 squares). This recorded increase may in part be due to differences in survey effort between the two atlases. On foot of this and informed by the long term range trend it is more appropriate to report the short-term trend as stable with an associated quality score of ‘moderate’.
The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 311 10km squares) using the same criteria.

(2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Cotton, D.C.F. 2004. Appendix B Flora and fauna. In: McGowan, J. Inishmurray: Island Voices. Aeolus. Hall, M.E., Newton, S., Suddaby, D. & Trewby, M. (2006) Seabird Productivity on the west coast of Ireland in 2006. NPWS Seabird Monitoring Project Report 2006. Leonard K. 2010. A survey of breeding Eiders Somateria mollissima in Northern Ireland in 2009. Irish Birds 9: 11-18.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The population estimate, considered to be a minimum estimate, is largely based on estimates from two sites within this species’ range in Ireland - Inishmurray Island, Co. Sligo with an estimated 100 pairs (Cotton 2004; Hall et al. 2006) and the Mullet Peninsula with an estimated 30 pairs (Suddaby pers comm). 30 pairs are estimated for the rest of the Irish range. Earlier all-Ireland estimates of 600 pairs by Gibbons et al. (with an estimated 250 pairs in Republic based on square occupancy) and 250-1000 pairs (BirdLife International 2004) are considered over estimates (Leonard 2010). The Northern Ireland population was estimated by Leonard (2010) at 1050 breeding females in 2009.

However the absence of reliable population estimates means that the magnitude of these increases cannot be reported. Therefore both the short- and the long-term trends are reported here as 'unknown'. The Northern Ireland population is considered to have increased ten-fold since 1977 (Leonard, 2010).

population_trend_method.desc: Absent data

population_trend_long_method.desc: Absent data

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Merne, O.J. (1986) Greylag Geese in Ireland - March 1986. Irish Birds 3: 207-214.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The resident Greylag Goose population in Ireland has descended from released birds and is therefore referred to as feral (Boland & Crowe 2008). There has been no systematic survey of breeding Greylag Geese in recent years. Data for the 1990’s was derived from a correspondence survey carried out by Brown & O’Halloran (1997). Although considered to be increasing in abundance no robust magnitude for this increase could be estimated. Therefore the short-term trend is reported here as ‘unknown’. The 1968-72 Breeding Atlas did not report on any breeding records in the Republic (Sharrock 1976). At the end of the overwintering season in 1986 Merne (1986) identified feral geese occurring in the Republic and in larger numbers in Northern Ireland. Based in part on the short-term range increase (section 5) the long term population trend is considered to be increasing. As the geese can winter in different areas compared to their breeding sites quantifying the breeding population for the Republic of Ireland for 1986 was not attempted and therefore no magnitude of the long-term increase was produced. Therefore the long-term trend is described as ‘unknown’.

The start point for assessing the long-term trend is Merne’s (1986) paper but no estimate of the magnitude of the increase is reported here due to lack of relevant data.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: An historical estimate of breeding densities was used to generate a current population estimate. Similar methods were applied in earlier bird atlases (Sharrock 1976; Gibbons et al. 1993) to generate all-Ireland population estimates for breeding Teal. Such estimates should be treated with caution due to the limited work that underlies the estimated density values and due the age of the estimate. Although the short-term range is estimated to have increased since the 1988-91 period this may in part be due to differences in survey effort between the atlases. Therefore it is suggested that the population has remained broadly stable in the short term. Between the first and most recent atlases (i.e. 1968-72 to 2007-2011) a 43% decline in the range is recorded (see section 4). With such a sizeable decline in the range recorded it is inevitable that a significant decline in the population also occurred during this period. However due to the nature of the available density estimates the magnitude of this decline is not calculated here.

This recorded increase may in part be due to a difference in survey effort and therefore the quality of this estimate is regarded to be of moderate quality. The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 311 10km squares) using the same criteria.

bird_report.population_additional_info: A naturalised goose census which was conducted in 2000 surveyed breeding Canada Goose populations in counties Cavan and Monaghan with 165 adults and 123 goslings reported (Rowell et al 2004). The number of breeding pairs reported here is an approximation derived by dividing the number of adults by two. As birds may have bred elsewhere this estimate should be considered to be a minimum estimate.

population_trend_method.desc: Absent data

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Lovatt, J. (1999) Occurrence of introduced Canada Goose Branta canadensis in Co. Cavan. Irish Birds 6:434-438
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
There has been little work surveying naturalised Canada Geese in Ireland since 2000 (see Rowell 2004). Therefore no contemporary population estimate of breeding pairs or its associated short-term trend can be reported here.
In 1986 a minimum of 3 pairs were breeding in the Republic (see Lovatt 1999). When this is compared with data from 2000 an increase of 2633% is calculated.

The long-term trend is measured from 1986 and the 3 pairs recorded breeding in one 10km square reported by Lovatt (1999). The magnitude of the long term increase should be treated with caution as other feral Canada Goose populations may also have established themselves in the Republic by the mid-1980s.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Referencing several sources Gibbons et al (1993) suggests that the all-Ireland breeding population in 1991 was 3,000 – 4,000 breeding pairs. This proportionately equates to an estimated 2475-3300 breeding pairs for the Republic in that period. Using the same estimates as Gibbons et al (1993) and factoring in the decrease in range reported by Balmer et al (2013) produces a contemporary population estimate of 2316-3087 pairs. This estimate is to be treated with caution because of the assumptions involved.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The contemporary population estimate was calculated using the number of occupied squares in Balmer et al (2013) and the density figure given in Gibbons et al (1993). The recorded decrease in range (section 5) indicates a population decline over the short term. In the absence of more comprehensive population data the magnitude of this suggested decline cannot be reported here. Therefore the trend has to be reported as 'unknown'. The long-term trend measured by the change in range between Sharrock (1976) and Balmer et al (2013) has been a decline but given the uncertainties of the population survey data, the magnitude cannot be reported here. In the absence of more comprehensive population data the magnitude of this suggested decline cannot be reported here. Therefore the trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

bird_report.range_additional_info:
The current species distribution and range map was generated using relevant data on confirmed, and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). This amounted to a total of 145 10km squares. A further 58 10km squares that held possible breeding records for this species are not presented here (see Balmer 2013).
This breeding species is primarily associated with coastal habitats. The Range Tool was used to define the initial range but all those inland 10km range squares that were not directly associated with a breeding record and did not intersect the coast were removed from the final range.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The contemporary population estimate is based on the current number of occupied 10km squares as per Balmer et al (2013) and on the estimated density figure as suggested by Sharrock (1976; 20 pairs per 10km square). As such this population estimate should be treated with caution. This is further compounded by the fact that the population is annually increased by an unknown and variable number of artificially reared birds. The long-term range change for this species is stable (section 5) so relying on this the long-term population trend for the prescribed period is also estimated to be stable. Although the short-term range recorded a 10% increase (section 5) due to the fact that the population is annually increased by an unknown and variable number of artificially reared birds, it is considered more appropriate to assess the short-term trend for the prescribed period as being broadly stable.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Gibbons et al (1991) estimated the all-Ireland breeding population at 850 – 1,700 breeding pairs. Using the proportion of all occupied records occurring in the Republic compared to those exclusively occurring in Northern Ireland a scaled population estimate for 1991 is calculated to be 638 – 1,275 breeding pairs for the Republic. Relying on the range increase data sourced from the recent Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) and assuming that the breeding density has remained unchanged since 1991 then a contemporary population of 974 – 1,969 breeding pairs is arrived at. This estimate is to be treated with caution on account of the difficulty involved in surveying for this species and due to the age of the density estimate.

British Trust for Ornithology. BirdLife International (2004) Birds in Europe: population estimates, trends and conservation status. Cambridge, UK: BirdLife International. (BirdLife Conservation Series No. 12). Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.
bird_report.population_additional_info: No dedicated national survey has been conducted to estimate the breeding population size of Woodcock in Ireland. Furthermore due to the crepuscular behaviour of this species which is associated with woodlands the methodology and timing of activities employed by previous bird atlases did not directly lead to robust population estimates (see Gibbons et al 1993). However ‘Birds in Europe II’ supplied a population estimate in part based on the breeding range as reported in Gibbons’ Breeding Atlas (BirdLife International, 2004). As there has been no significant subsequent change in the reported breeding range of Woodcock in Ireland (Balmer et al 2013) the ‘Birds in Europe II’ population estimate of 2500 – 9999 breeding pairs may still be relevant to this time period. However the recommended reporting unit is calling males and due to the uncertainly that exists between the ratio of calling males to breeding pairs no reliable population estimate can be reported here.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info:
The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the number of relevant occupied 10km squares from the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013; 131 10km squares) with those of the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993; 136 10km squares). A relatively small decrease of 4% is calculated but due to the difficulty in comprehensively surveying this secretive species, a stable trend assessment has been considered more appropriate.
The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 403 10km squares) using the same criteria.

British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Gibbons et al (1993) estimated the all-Ireland breeding population in 1991 at 1,250 breeding pairs. Using the proportion of occupied 10km squares occurring in the Republic compared to those exclusively occurring in Northern Ireland a scaled population estimate for 1991 is calculated to be 1,045 breeding pairs for the Republic for that period. As the recorded breeding range did not change in the short term (see section 5) and assuming that the breeding density has remained unchanged since 1991 then a contemporary population estimate of 1,045 breeding pairs is arrived at. This estimate is to be treated with caution.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: As the contemporary population estimate is primarily derived from the population estimate set out in Gibbons et al (1993) and the number of occupied 10km squares recorded during the 2007-11 Bird Atlas both the long- and the short-term population trend estimates are informed by the respective range trend estimates (section 5). Although the short term range trend records an increase it is considered more appropriate, given the relatively small size of the increase, to describe the short-term trend as being broadly stable. Over the long-term a significant decline in the breeding range has been recorded but due to an insufficiency of population survey data the magnitude of this population trend is not estimated. Therefore the long-term trend is reported here as ‘unknown’.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info:
The current species distribution and range map was generated using relevant data on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). This amounted to a total of 182 10km squares. A further 22 10km squares that held possible breeding records for this species are not presented here (see Balmer 2013).
This breeding species is primarily associated with coastal habitats. The Range Tool was used to define the initial range but all those inland 10km range squares that were not directly associated with a breeding record and did not intersect the coast were removed from the final range.

range_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.

range_trend_long_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the number of relevant occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013; 204 10km squares) with those of the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993; 202 10km squares). Although an increase of 1% is calculated it is considered more appropriate to describe the trend as being broadly stable. The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 269 10km squares) using the same criteria.

population_type_of_estimate.desc: Estimate derived from sample survey

population_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_sources: Crowe, O., Musgrove, A.J. & O'Halloran, J. (2014). Generating population estimates for common and widespread breeding birds in Ireland. Bird Study 61 (1) 82 - 90.
bird_report.population_additional_info:
Crowe et al (2014) Generated densities of common and widespread breeding birds using data from annual bird monitoring surveys using count data of individual adults seen or heard for all years between 2006 and 2010 inclusive. Bird atlas data were then used to (1) quantify the distribution of each species (10-km squares), and (2) generate an estimate of proportion occurrence of each species within each square. The total number of birds of each species was generated by multiplying proportion occupancy by the total area of the 10-km square and by the mean regional density generated from the bird monitoring data, and by summing the estimates of squares.
The estimates generated by Crowe et al (2014) are based on individuals and no attempts are made to convert individuals to breeding pairs or to account for differences in detectability between the sexes. However in Table 1 of this paper the authors have attempted to provide an indication based on judgement from a number of ornithological experts in Britain and Ireland on the approximate proportion of the true breeding populations that are estimated here.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Crowe, O. (2013). Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Estimate based on expert opinion with no or minimal sampling

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Expert opinion - O. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland, http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment and no large change (arbitrarily set at >10% in this context) in the recorded long-term breeding range trend was noted (see section 5). For this common and widespread species a significant change in population abundances may occur and not result in any marked changes in the reported breeding range therefore the long-term population trend for this species is assigned an ‘unknown’ status.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: The current species distribution map was generated using data on confirmed, probable and possible breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map.

range_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

(2013) BirdTrends 2012: trends in numbers, breeding success and survival for UK breeding birds. BTO Research Report No. 644. BTO, Thetford. http://www.bto.org/birdtrends. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland, http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment. Although the long-term breeding range is broadly stable (arbitrarily set at +/-10% in this context) it is likely that the long-term population trend is increasing. This assessment is informed by the increasing short-term population trend since 1998 (Crowe 2013) and recorded long-term increases in the UK (Baillie et al 2013). Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this increase is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the abundance of relevant occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with those of the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993). The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976) using the same criteria.

population_type_of_estimate.desc: Estimate derived from sample survey

population_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_sources: Crowe, O., Musgrove, A.J. & O'Halloran, J. (2014). Generating population estimates for common and widespread breeding birds in Ireland. Bird Study 61 (1) 82 - 90.
bird_report.population_additional_info:
Crowe et al (2014) Generated densities of common and widespread breeding birds using data from annual bird monitoring surveys using count data of individual adults seen or heard for all years between 2006 and 2010 inclusive. Bird atlas data were then used to (1) quantify the distribution of each species (10-km squares), and (2) generate an estimate of proportion occurrence of each species within each square. The total number of birds of each species was generated by multiplying proportion occupancy by the total area of the 10-km square and by the mean regional density generated from the bird monitoring data, and by summing the estimates of squares.
The estimates generated by Crowe et al (2014) are based on individuals and no attempts are made to convert individuals to breeding pairs or to account for differences in detectability between the sexes. However in Table 1 of this paper the authors have attempted to provide an indication based on judgement from a number of ornithological experts in Britain and Ireland on the approximate proportion of the true breeding populations that are estimated here.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Crowe, O. (2013). Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Absent data

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Baillie, S.R., Marchant, J.H., Leech, D.I., Massimino, D., Eglington, S.M., Johnston, A., Noble, D.G., Barimore, C., Kew, A.J., Downie, I.S., Risely, K. & Robinson, R.A. (2013) BirdTrends 2012: trends in numbers, breeding success and survival for UK breeding birds. BTO Research Report No. 644. BTO, Thetford. http://www.bto.org/birdtrends. Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Crowe, O. (2013) Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report. Expert opinion: O. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland, http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment. Although the long-term breeding range is broadly stable (arbitrarily set at +/-10% in this context) it is likely that the long-term population trend is increasing. This assessment is informed by the increasing short-term population trend since 1998 (Crowe 2013) and recorded long-term increases in the UK (Baillie et al 2013). Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this increase is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate
