bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Expert opinion - O. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland, http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). The mean annual change (-0.05) for Cuckoo is indicating stability, however, the short term population change since 1998, results in a recorded decline of 5.8% (Note: the short-term trend was assessed as stable - see section 3.1). Most of the breeding range losses (27%) for Cuckoo, occurred between the 1968-72 and 1988-91 breeding atlases (Sharrock 1976; Gibbons et al. 1993), with a decline from 811 10km squares to 595 10km squares with breeding records. Since 1988-91, the breeding range has shown a slight increase to 603 10km squares (an increase of 1.3%) by 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment but relying primarily on the recorded decrease in the long-term breeding range (see section 5) the long-term population trend is considered to be a decreasing one. Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this decrease is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

The estimates generated by Crowe et al (2014) are based on individuals and no attempts are made to convert individuals to breeding pairs or to account for differences in detectability between the sexes. However in Table 1 of this paper the authors have attempted to provide an indication based on judgement from a number of ornithological experts in Britain and Ireland on the approximate proportion of the true breeding populations that are estimated here.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Crowe, O. (2013). Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Absent data

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Baillie, S.R., Marchant, J.H., Leech, D.I., Massimino, D., Eglington, S.M., Johnston, A., Noble, D.G., Barimore, C., Kew, A.J., Downie, I.S., Risely, K. & Robinson, R.A. (2013) BirdTrends 2012: trends in numbers, breeding success and survival for UK breeding birds. BTO Research Report No. 644. BTO, Thetford. http://www.bto.org/birdtrends. Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology Crowe, O. bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment. Although the long-term breeding range is broadly stable (arbitrarily set at +/-10% in this context) it is likely that the long-term population trend is increasing. This assessment is informed by the increasing short-term population trend since 1998 (Crowe 2013) and recorded long-term increases in the UK (Baillie et al 2013). Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this increase is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the abundance of relevant occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with those of the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993). The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976) using the same criteria.

population_type_of_estimate.desc: Estimate derived from sample survey

population_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_sources: Crowe, O., Musgrove, A.J. & O'Halloran, J. (2014). Generating population estimates for common and widespread breeding birds in Ireland. Bird Study 61 (1) 82 - 90.
bird_report.population_additional_info:
Crowe et al (2014) Generated densities of common and widespread breeding birds using data from annual bird monitoring surveys using count data of individual adults seen or heard for all years between 2006 and 2010 inclusive. Bird atlas data were then used to (1) quantify the distribution of each species (10-km squares), and (2) generate an estimate of proportion occurrence of each species within each square. The total number of birds of each species was generated by multiplying proportion occupancy by the total area of the 10-km square and by the mean regional density generated from the bird monitoring data, and by summing the estimates of squares.
The estimates generated by Crowe et al (2014) are based on individuals and no attempts are made to convert individuals to breeding pairs or to account for differences in detectability between the sexes. However in Table 1 of this paper the authors have attempted to provide an indication based on judgement from a number of ornithological experts in Britain and Ireland on the approximate proportion of the true breeding populations that are estimated here.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Crowe, O. (2013). Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Estimate based on expert opinion with no or minimal sampling

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment and no large change (arbitrarily set at >10% in this context) in the recorded long-term breeding range trend was noted (see section 5). For this common and widespread species a significant change in population abundances may occur and not result in any marked changes in the reported breeding range therefore the long-term population trend for this species is assigned an ‘unknown’ status.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Expert opinion - O. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland, http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). Categorising the short term population trend for this species was difficult as there were differences in the results of short term population trends, a decline of 14% since 1998 (Note: this decline is not statistically significant), and the mean annual change figures, which indicate the population is stable (-1.2). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment but relying primarily on the recorded increase in the long-term breeding range (see section 5) the long-term population trend is considered to be an increasing one. Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this increase is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

However in Table 1 of this paper the authors have attempted to provide an indication based on judgement from a number of ornithological experts in Britain and Ireland on the approximate proportion of the true breeding populations that are estimated here.

No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment. Although the long-term breeding range is broadly stable (arbitrarily set at +/-10% in this context) it is likely that the long-term population trend is increasing. This assessment is informed by the increasing short-term population trend since 1998 (Crowe 2013) and recorded long-term increases in the UK (Baillie et al 2013). Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this increase is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). Although the mean annual change figures indicate the population is stable (1.0), the short term breeding range increase of 20.7% and the short term population recorded an increase of 14.1% since 1998, suggest the population may be increasing in the short term (Note that the short-term trend was not statistically significant and is assessed as being stable). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment and no large change (arbitrarily set at >10% in this context) in the recorded long-term breeding range trend was noted (see section 5). For this common and widespread species a significant change in population abundances may occur and not result in any marked changes in the reported breeding range therefore the long-term population trend for this species is assigned an ‘unknown’ status.

However in Table 1 of this paper the authors have attempted to provide an indication based on judgement from a number of ornithological experts in Britain and Ireland on the approximate proportion of the true breeding populations that are estimated here.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment and no large change (arbitrarily set at >10% in this context) in the recorded long-term breeding range trend was noted (see section 5). For this common and widespread species a significant change in population abundances may occur and not result in any marked changes in the reported breeding range therefore the long-term population trend for this species is assigned an ‘unknown’ status.

(2013) BirdTrends 2012: trends in numbers, breeding success and survival for UK breeding birds. BTO Research Report No. 644. BTO, Thetford; http://www.bto.org/birdtrends. Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment. Although the long-term breeding range is broadly stable (arbitrarily set at +/-10% in this context) it is likely that the long-term population trend is increasing. This assessment is informed by the increasing short-term population trend since 1998 (Crowe 2013) and recorded long-term increases in the UK (Baillie et al 2013). Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this increase is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

This assessment is informed by the decreasing short-term population trend since 1998 (Crowe 2013) and recorded long-term decreases in the UK (Baillie et al 2013). Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this decrease is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: The current species distribution map was generated using data on confirmed, probable and possible breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the abundance of relevant occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with those of the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993). The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976) using the same criteria.

population_type_of_estimate.desc: Estimate derived from sample survey

population_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_sources: Crowe, O., Musgrove, A.J. & O'Halloran, J. (2014). Generating population estimates for common and widespread breeding birds in Ireland. Bird Study 61 (1) 82 - 90.
bird_report.population_additional_info:
Crowe et al (2014) Generated densities of common and widespread breeding birds using data from annual bird monitoring surveys using count data of individual adults seen or heard for all years between 2006 and 2010 inclusive. Bird atlas data were then used to (1) quantify the distribution of each species (10-km squares), and (2) generate an estimate of proportion occurrence of each species within each square. The total number of birds of each species was generated by multiplying proportion occupancy by the total area of the 10-km square and by the mean regional density generated from the bird monitoring data, and by summing the estimates of squares.
The estimates generated by Crowe et al (2014) are based on individuals and no attempts are made to convert individuals to breeding pairs or to account for differences in detectability between the sexes. However in Table 1 of this paper the authors have attempted to provide an indication based on judgement from a number of ornithological experts in Britain and Ireland on the approximate proportion of the true breeding populations that are estimated here.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Crowe, O. (2013). Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Absent data

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Expert opinion - O. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland, http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment but relying primarily on the recorded decrease in the long-term breeding range (see section 5) the long-term population trend is considered to be a decreasing one. Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this decrease is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: This species is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS). However the short-term trend for Treecreeper is 'uncertain' due to the fact that the variation within the CBS dataset is large and the sample of plots is too small to give a meaningful result. Hence the short term trend has been categorised as 'unknown' status. No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment and no large change (arbitarily set at >10% in this context) in the recorded long-term breeding range trend was noted (see section 5). For this common and widespread species a significant change in population abundances may occur and not result in any marked changes in the reported breeding range therefore the long-term population trend for this species is assigned an 'unknown' status.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Baillie, S.R., Marchant, J.H., Leech, D.I., Massimino, D., Eglington, S.M., Johnston, A., Noble, D.G., Barimore, C., Kew, A.J., Downie, I.S., Risely, K. & Robinson, R.A. (2013) BirdTrends 2012: trends in numbers, breeding success and survival for UK breeding birds. BTO Research Report No. 644. BTO, Thetford. http://www.bto.org/birdtrends. Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Crowe, O. (2013) Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report. Expert opinion: O. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland, http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment. Although no large change in the long-term breeding range was recorded (arbitrarily set at > 10% in this context) it is likely that the long-term population trend is increasing. This assessment is informed by the increasing short-term population trend since 1998 (Crowe 2013) and recorded long-term increases in the UK (Baillie et al 2013).

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the abundance of relevant occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2007-2011 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with those of the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993). The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976) using the same criteria.

population_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_sources: Crowe, O., Musgrove, A.J. & O'Halloran, J. (2014). Generating population estimates for common and widespread breeding birds in Ireland. Bird Study 61 (1) 82 - 90.
bird_report.population_additional_info:
Crowe et al (2014) Generated densities of common and widespread breeding birds using data from annual bird monitoring surveys using count data of individual adults seen or heard for all years between 2006 and 2010 inclusive. Bird atlas data were then used to (1) quantify the distribution of each species (10-km squares), and (2) generate an estimate of proportion occurrence of each species within each square. The total number of birds of each species was generated by multiplying proportion occupancy by the total area of the 10-km square and by the mean regional density generated from the bird monitoring data, and by summing the estimates of squares.
The estimates generated by Crowe et al (2014) are based on individuals and no attempts are made to convert individuals to breeding pairs or to account for differences in detectability between the sexes. However in Table 1 of this paper the authors have attempted to provide an indication based on judgement from a number of ornithological experts in Britain and Ireland on the approximate proportion of the true breeding populations that are estimated here.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment and no large change (arbitrarily set at >10% in this context) in the recorded long-term breeding range trend was noted (see section 5). For this common and widespread species a significant change in population abundances may occur and not result in any marked changes in the reported breeding range therefore the long-term population trend for this species is assigned an ‘unknown’ status.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Baillie, S.R., Marchant, J.H., Leech, D.I., Massimino, D., Eglington, S.M., Johnston, A., Noble, D.G., Barimore, C., Kew, A.J., Downie, I.S., Risely, K. & Robinson, R.A. (2013) BirdTrends 2012: trends in numbers, breeding success and survival for UK breeding birds. BTO Research Report No. 644. BTO, Thetford; http://www.bto.org/birdtrends. Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Crowe, O. (2013) Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report. Expert opinion - O. Crowe, BirdWatch Ireland, http://birdwatchireland.ie/. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment. Although the long-term breeding range is broadly stable (arbitrarily set at +/-10% in this context) it is likely that the long-term population trend is increasing (this assessment is informed by the increasing short-term population trend since 1998 (Crowe 2013) and recorded long-term increases in the UK (Baillie et al 2013)). However the magnitude of this increase is not estimated here due to an insufficiency of data and so the long-term population trend is reported as ‘unknown’.

No long-term comprehensive population data was available for this assessment but relying primarily on the recorded decrease in the long-term breeding range (see section 5) the long-term population trend is considered to be a decreasing one. Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this decrease is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

bird_report.population_sources: Dr Marc Ruddock, Red Kite Project Officer, Golden Eagle Trust Ltd (http://www.goldeneagle.ie/).
bird_report.population_additional_info: Red Kite was recently re-introduced into Ireland. The population estimate is based on the number of territorial pairs that attempted to nest in 2012 (see http://www.goldeneagle.ie/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&layout=item&id=615&Itemid=215).
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Since its extinction in Ireland over 200 years ago Red Kite has not bred in the wild in Ireland until very recently. This species is the subject of a re-introduction programme and birds have only started to breed successfully since 2010. Therefore no long-term or short term trends are presented here.

range_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.range_sources: Dr Marc Ruddock, Red Kite Project Officer, Golden Eagle Trust Ltd (http://www.goldeneagle.ie/).
bird_report.range_additional_info: The distribution refers to those eleven 10km grid squares that held the 17 territorial pairs that attempted to nest in 2012. The Range Tool was used and was coincident with the distribution.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Since its extinction in Ireland over 200 years ago Red Kite has not bred in the wild in Ireland until very recently. This species is the subject of a re-introduction programme and birds have only started to breed successfully since 2010. Therefore no long-term or short term trends are presented here.
bird_report.measures_taken: Several Red Kite carcasses have tested positive for second generation anticoagulant rodenticides. This along with deliberate illegal poisoning events is a cause for concern. The Campaign for Responsible Rodenticide Use is in startup stage here.
bird_report.further_information: NPWS Bird of Prey Poisoning: http://www.npws.ie/news/name,15121,en.html

population_type_of_estimate.desc: The best available single figure or range

population_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_sources: Lorcan O’Toole, Golden Eagle Re-introduction Project Officer (http://www.goldeneagle.ie/).
bird_report.population_additional_info: The population estimate for this re-introduced species is based on the number of territorial pairs that attempted to breed during the period 2011-2012 (see http://www.goldeneagle.ie/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&layout=item&id=610&Itemid=105).

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Lorcan O’Toole, Golden Eagle Re-introduction Project Officer (http://www.goldeneagle.ie/)
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The Golden Eagle became extinct as a breeding species in Ireland approximately 100 years ago. As part of an on-going programme to reintroduce Golden Eagles to the northwest of Ireland, 61 young Golden Eagles chicks, collected from Scotland, have been released in Glenveagh National Park, County Donegal between 2001-2007. As a result of this project, in 2004, a pair established a territory and in 2005 a pair bred. Therefore only a short term trend and no long term trend (i.e. from 1980) is presented here (see http://www.goldeneagle.ie/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&layout=item&id=610&Itemid=105).

range_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.range_sources: Lorcan O’Toole, Golden Eagle Re-introduction Project Officer (http://www.goldeneagle.ie/).
bird_report.range_additional_info: The range relates to the sum of 10km grid squares where Golden Eagles attempted to breed during the period 2011-2012. As this is a sensitive species mapping of its distribution and range is at the 50km level.

range_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.range_trend_sources: Lorcan O’Toole, Golden Eagle Re-introduction Project Officer (http://www.goldeneagle.ie/).
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The Golden Eagle became extinct as a breeding species in Ireland approximately 100 years ago. As part of an on-going programme to reintroduce Golden Eagles to the northwest of Ireland, 61 young Golden Eagles chicks, collected from Scotland, have been released in Glenveagh National Park, County Donegal between 2001-2007. As a result of this project, in 2004, a pair established a territory and in 2005 a pair bred. Therefore only a short term trend and no long term trend (i.e. from 1980) is presented here (see http://www.goldeneagle.ie/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&layout=item&id=610&Itemid=105).

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info:

Long-term trend: This trend was informed by Partridge (1988 & 1989) and his account of Common Scoter as provided in Gibbons et al (1993).

bird_report.population_additional_info: The national population of Grey Partridge is subject to a range of comprehensive conservation management measures including a captive breeding programme which began in 2002 (http://www.greypartridge.ie).

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

(2012) Every Partridge counts, successful techniques used in the captive conservation breeding programme for wild grey partridge in Ireland. Animal Biodiversity and Conservation 35 (2) 387-393.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Absent data

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Buckley, K., Kelly, P., Kavanagh, B., O’Gorman, E.C., Carnus, T. and McMahon, B.J. (2012) Every Partridge counts, successful techniques used in the captive conservation breeding programme for wild grey partridge in Ireland. Animal Biodiversity and Conservation 35 (2) 387-393. Gibbons, D.W., Reid, J.B. and Chapman, R.A. 1993. The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland: 1988–1991. T. & A.D. Poyser, London. Lack, P. C. 1986. The Atlas of Wintering Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & T. A. Poyser,Calton. Sharrock, J. T. R. 1976. The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & A. D. Poyser, Berkhamsted. Whilde, A. (1993) Threatened mammals, birds, amphibians and fish in Ireland. Irish Red Data book 2: Vertebrates. Belfast, HMSO.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Buckley et al (2012) estimated the 2001 population at 4 – 6 pairs. Using the midpoints for this and for the contemporary population estimate (section 2.2) an estimated increase of some 3700% is calculated. Informed by the severe long-term range decline (section 5) it is considered that this species underwent a long-term population decline. Due to a lack of survey data the magnitude of this decline is not estimated here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

range_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.range_sources: National expert: Kieran Buckley; http://www.npws.ie.
bird_report.range_additional_info:
The 2012 breeding distribution is based on unpublished survey data of breeding Grey Partridge directly associated with the Grey Partridge Conservation Programme and on expert opinion (Kieran Buckley).
The recommended Range Tool was used and only those six 10km squares that constituted the 2012 distribution were identified as being part of the range.

range_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London. Lack, P. C. (1986) The Atlas of Wintering Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & T. A. Poyser,Calton. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info:
Short-term breeding range trend: By 2001 the wild Grey Partridge breeding population was restricted to just one area which overlapped with four 10km squares.
Long-term breeding range trend: There is no breeding distribution data available for 1980 and this is in the middle of the first two breeding atlases (i.e. Sharrock et al 1976 and Gibbons et al 1993). This species underwent a significant range decline between these aforementioned breeding atlases. There is no breeding distribution data available for the early 1980’s. However a wintering bird atlas was produced from data collected over the winters of 1981/82 to 1983/84 (Lack 1986). As this species is relatively sedentary we have tentatively used the winter distribution as a proxy to describe a breeding one. During this period 23 10km squares were identified with Grey Partridge records. Some artificially reared birds released into the wild for hunting purposes may have been included in these records.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Gibbons et al (1993) estimated the population to be < 30 pairs but extant. No breeding evidence was reported by Balmer et al (2013) or by the IRBBP (2012). Hence this species is deemed to have gone extinct as a breeding bird in the intervening period.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Extinct as a breeding bird by the late 1990's Corn Bunting was once a widespread breeding species in Ireland but its abundance and range declined significantly through the last century and by the early 1980s this species was considered to be rare (Hutchinson 1989). Neither Balmer (2013) nor Hillis (2012) recorded this species as breeding in recent times. Tucker and Heath (1994) estimated the 1980 population at 30 pairs.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Now extinct as a breeding bird Corn Bunting was once a widespread breeding species in Ireland but its abundance and range declined significantly through the last century and by the early 1980s this species was considered to be rare (Hutchinson 1989). Neither Balmer (2013) nor Hillis (2012) recorded this species as breeding in recent times. Sharrock (1976) recorded this species in 55 10km squares during the atlas fieldwork (i.e. 1968 - 72).

bird_report.population_sources: Cummins, S., Fisher, J., Gaj McKeever, R., McNaghten, L & Crowe, O. (2010) Assessment of the distribution and abundance of Kingfisher Alcedo atthis and other riparian birds on six SAC river systems in Ireland. A report commissioned by the National Parks and Wildlife Service and prepared by BirdWatch Ireland, Kicoole, Co Wicklow. Environmental Protection Agency Geoportal Website; http://gis.epa.ie/.
bird_report.population_additional_info: A series of kingfisher surveys were undertaken during the breeding season of 2010 at six representative river systems (Cummins et al 2010). The range of abundances estimated from these surveys was extrapolated using an EPA dataset of rivers in Ireland to produce a national population estimate. As the sample size of the recorded abundances is quite small this extrapolated population estimate should be treated with caution.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Gibbons, D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Tucker, G.M. & Heath, M.F. (1994) Birds in Europe: their conservation status. BirdLife International (BirdLife Conservation Series No. 3), Cambridge, UK.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Following the assumed density of 3 – 5 breeding pairs of Kingfisher per occupied square taken from Sharrock (1976), Gibbons et al estimated the all-Irish breeding population at 1,300 – 2,100 pairs. Scaling this for the proportion of occupied squares recorded in the Republic results in a national population estimate of 986 – 1582 pairs for the period 1988 – 1991. Comparing the midpoints of this estimate with the contemporary estimate a population decline of 45% is calculated. To derive a long-term population trend the contemporary population estimate was compared with the estimate of 900 – 1,600 pairs given by Tucker and Heath (1994). Applying the same criteria as the short-term trend a 44% decline is derived. Only the 2010 population estimate was based on abundances per unit length of river and compared against other estimates which were largely based on breeding atlas densities and best expert opinion and as such the estimated trends should be treated with caution.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: The current species distribution map was generated using data on confirmed, probable and possible breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the amount of relevant occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2007-11 Atlas (Balmer et al 2013; 334 10km squares) with those of the 1988-91 Breeding Atlas (Gibbons et al 1993; 232 10km squares). The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 Breeding Atlas (Sharrock 1976; 421 10km squares) using the same criteria.

Duff, (2010) Breeding Status of Red-throated Divers in Donegal in 2010. Unpublished report. Duff, N.(2011) Report on contract to survey breeding Red-throated Divers in 2011. Unpublished report. (2012) Report of the breeding status of Red-throated Divers in Donegal, 2012. Unpublished report.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Based on data presented in Cromie (2002) the average number of confirmed and probable pairs recorded during the period 1998-2002 was used in the short term trend calculation which amounted to over four breeding pairs. An uneven amount of survey effort and coverage throughout this review period may have led to an overestimation of this increasing trend. Primarily relying on data from the first breeding bird atlas (Sharrock 1976) Hutchinson (1989) estimated that the early to mid 1980’s population was unchanged from that of the 1970’s which was estimated to be less than ten pairs. As this is broadly similar to the more recent population estimates the long term trend is deemed to be stable.

(2010) Breeding Status of Red-throated Divers in Donegal in 2010. Unpublished report. Duff, N.(2011) Report on contract to survey breeding Red-throated Divers in 2011. Unpublished report. Hutchinson C.D. (1989) Birds in Ireland. T & AD Poyser, Staffordshire. McLoughlin, D. and Beaubier, J.E. (2009) Breeding Status of red-throated diver in County Donegal, 2009 Report on contracted fieldwork. Unpublished report. Wheeldon, R (2012) Report of the breeding status of Red-throated Divers in Donegal, 2012. Unpublished report.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short term breeding range trend is based on a comparison of the number of 10km squares that held confirmed or probable breeding pairs as outlined in Cromie (2002) and the number of 10km squares of known occupied breeding territories as reported by the fieldworkers of the Red-throated Diver Conservation project over the period 2008-2012 inclusive. Although an increase of 50% is calculated it should be noted that the species is difficult to survey and due to restricted range of this species in Ireland an underestimate of the true number of occupied 10km squares could result in a large percentage change between survey periods. The long term breeding range is informed by the first breeding bird atlas of Sharrock (1976) which reported on a total of four 10km squares that held confirmed or probable breeding records with a further three 10km squares with possible records. This species is difficult to survey in Ireland and so a direct comparison of confirmed/proven 10km squares with more recent results would describe a likely exaggerated range increase. Therefore and informed by Hutchinson (1989) a stable trend is deemed to be a more appropriate description.

bird_report.population_sources: Gray, N., Thomas, G., Trewby, M. & Newton, S. (2003) The status and distribution of Choughs Pyrrhocorax pyrrhocorax in the Republic of Ireland 2002/03. Irish Birds 7: 147-156.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The last national survey for Chough was conducted over two breeding seasons in 2002 and 2003. Coverage was comprehensive at the main coastal habitats but less so for some mountainous inland areas (e.g. Counties Cork and Kerry).

population_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Berrow, S.D., Mackie, K.L., O’Sullivan, O., Shepherd, K.B., Mellon, C. & Coveney, J.A. (1993) The second International Chough Survey in Ireland. Irish Birds 5: 1-10. Gray, N., Thomas, G., Trewby, M. & Newton, S. (2003) The status and distribution of Choughs Pyrrhocorax pyrrhocorax in the Republic of Ireland 2002/03. Irish Birds 7: 147-156. Expert opinion: M. Trewby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie/.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Bullock, I.D., Drewett, D.R. & Mickleburgh, S.P. (1983) The Chough in Ireland. Irish Birds 2:257-271. Gray, N., Thomas, G., Trewby, M. & Newton, S. (2003) The status and distribution of Choughs Pyrrhocorax pyrrhocorax in the Republic of Ireland 2002/03. Irish Birds 7: 147-156.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Short-term population trend: Overall, an 8 % decrease in the total number of Choughs was recorded between the two most recent national censuses in 1992 and 2002-03 (Gray et al. 2003). Due to differences in coverage, methodology and data analysis the 2002-03 census was judged to be the more conservative of the two population estimates. Therefore the calculated decline is thought to be an overestimate. Allowing for natural fluctuations in the population the overall assessment for Ireland’s Chough population was one of relative stability between 1992 and 2002-03. Long-term population trend: The long-term population trend was calculated by comparing the 1982 survey results of 647-675 breeding pairs in the Republic of Ireland (Bullock et al. 1983) with the most recent Chough survey (Gray et al. 2003) which showed an overall increase of 24-30% in the breeding population. However, as fewer sites were covered in the 1982 survey, the purported increase is likely to be an overestimate and therefore therefore quality of this increase has been categorised as moderate.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: All confirmed and probable breeding records from the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) formed the basis of the Chough breeding distribution map. The recommended Range Tool was used to initially define the range. However as this is predominantly a coastal species only those inland 10km squares (i.e. those 10km squares that did not overlap with the coastline) that held breeding records were retained as part of the reported range. All those inland 10km squares that were selected by the Range Tool but did not contain a breeding record were subsequently removed from the reported range.

range_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gray, N., Thomas, G., Trewby, M. & Newton, S. (2003) The status and distribution of Choughs Pyrrhocorax pyrrhocorax in the Republic of Ireland 2002/03. Irish Birds 7: 147-156.

range_trend_long_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Bullock, I.D., Drewett, D.R.& Mickleburgh, S.P. (1983) The Chough in Ireland. Irish Birds 2:257-271.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the number of 10km squares that held breeding records of Chough as recorded by the 2002-2003 Chough Survey (Grey et al 2003) with those records from the 2007-2011 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013). This amounted to a 3% increase. This calculated increase for the short-term range is relatively small and due to the differences in survey methodologies between the 2002-03 Chough Survey and the 2007-11 Bird Atlas the trend is better described as being stable. The long-term range trend was calculated by comparing the number of 10km squares that held breeding records of Chough as recorded by the 1982 Chough Survey (Bullock et al 1983) with those relevant records from the 2007-2011 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013). This amounted to a 5% increase. This calculated increase for the long-term range is relatively small and due to the differences in survey methodologies between the 2082 Chough Survey and the 2007-11 Bird Atlas the trend is better described as being stable.

(2010) The status of Red Grouse in Ireland and the effects of land use, habitat and habitat quality on their distribution. Irish Wildlife Manuals No. 50, National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government, Dublin, Ireland; http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM50.pdf.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Based on the figures given in Cummins et al. (2010), males accounted for 55% of the national population. Assuming all females were paired, this would give an estimate of 1,898 (95% CL 1,708-2,116) breeding pairs.

(2010) The status of Red Grouse in Ireland and the effects of land use, habitat and habitat quality on their distribution. Irish Wildlife Manuals No. 50, National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government, Dublin, Ireland; http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM50.pdf. O’Hare, P.J. (1968 - 1972) Red Grouse Research in Ireland, An Fóras Taluntais. Unpublished Reports. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B, & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Expert opinion - S. Cummins, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie/. Cummins, S., Bleasdale, A., Douglas, C., Newton, S., O'Halloran, J. & Wilson, J.W. (2010). The status of Red Grouse in Ireland and the effects of land use, habitat and habitat quality on their distribution. Irish Wildlife Manuals No. 50, National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government, Dublin, Ireland; http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM50.pdf. Watson, A. & O'Hare, P.J. (1973) Experiments to increase Red Grouse stocks and improve the bogland environment. Biological Conservation 5: 41-44. O’Hare, P.J. (1968-72) Red Grouse Research in Ireland, An Fóras Taluntais. Unpublished reports.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The Red Grouse Survey 2006-08 estimated the national population to be 1,898 (95% CL 1,708-2,116) breeding pairs (Cummins et al. 2010). Both the short- and long-term population trends are based on Red Grouse breeding density information from O’Hare (1968 – 1972) and Cummins et al. (2010) combined with estimates of the area of suitable grouse habitat in 1980 and in 2000.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Cummins, S., Bleasdale, A., Douglas, C., Newton, S., O'Halloran, J. & Wilson, J.W. 2010. The status of Red Grouse in Ireland and the effects of land use, habitat and habitat quality on their distribution. Irish Wildlife Manuals No. 50, National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government, Dublin, Ireland. (http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM50.pdf).
bird_report.range_additional_info: In order to produce a realistic distribution map based on the Irish 10km grid squares it was considered most appropriate to select all those 10km squares that had records of Red Grouse that were specifically surveyed during the 2006-2008 National Red Grouse Survey (see Cummins et al 2010) which was conducted prior to the breeding period. Such an approach is justified as Red Grouse are largely sedentary. Records (confirmed, probable and possible) from the 2007-11 Bird Atlas supplemented this map. The recommended Range Tool was used to derive a range for this species and no subsequent modifications to this range were made.

range_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on expert opinion with no or minimal sampling

(2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Cummins, S., Bleasdale, A., Douglas, C., Newton, S., O'Halloran, J. & Wilson, J.W. (2010) The status of Red Grouse in Ireland and the effects of land use, habitat and habitat quality on their distribution. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London.

range_trend_long_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser. Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Cummins, S., Bleasdale, A., Douglas, C., Newton, S., O'Halloran, J. & Wilson, J.W. (2010) The status of Red Grouse in Ireland and the effects of land use, habitat and habitat quality on their distribution. Irish Wildlife Manuals No. 50, National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government, Dublin, Ireland; http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM50.pdf.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The long-term breeding range trend was calculated by comparing the distribution of Red Grouse during the period 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976) with the distribution as per Section 4. This reduction in range can be largely explained by changes in extent of suitable habitat and changes in habitat quality that occurred particularly in the first 20 years of the period (Cummins et al. 2010). If a similar approach is taken to produce a short-term trend based on the 1988-1991 breeding bird atlas (Gibbons et al 1993) then a calculated increase (57%) in breeding range is produced. It is the considered expert opinion (S. Cummins, BirdWatch Ireland) that this atlas under-recorded this species. Therefore this calculated range increase is not reported here as they would give a false picture of the decline of Red Grouse in Ireland. It is more likely that the breeding range of Red Grouse has not undergone an increase in the past 12 years, but rather has remained largely stable with the most acute losses in the range of the species occurring prior to 2000. Hence the short term trend has been assessed as stable.

National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht, Dublin, Ireland. Wilson-Parr, R. (2013) Wintering Hen Harrier, Article 12 information note. Unpublished note for NPWS.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Wilson-Parr (2013) estimates a mid-winter population range of 269-349 individuals. This estimate was produced primarily relying on data from the 2010 Hen Harrier breeding survey (see Ruddock et al 2012) but also incorporates estimates of breeding productivity, mortality rates and migration data from various sources.

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Norriss, D.W., Marsh, J., McMahon, D. & Oliver, G.A. (2002). A national survey of breeding hen harriers Circus cyaneus in Ireland 1998‐2000. Irish Birds 7: 1–10. bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Sharrock, J. T. R. 1976. The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & A. D. Poyser. Wilson-Parr, R. (2013) Hen Harrier overwintering in Ireland: population estimates and other topics related to Art 12 reporting. Unpublished note.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Using data from the 1998-2002 survey (Norriss et al 2002) and other data including relevant productivity rates a short term-trend was approximated. An estimate of the long term trend for mid-winter numbers of Hen harriers in Ireland was not possible due to a lack of data. Basing an estimate on the 1968 – 1972 Bird Atlas (Sharrock, 1976) was considered, however no published sources of productivity rates for Hen harriers in Ireland were available for this time period.

bird_report.population_sources: Boland, H. & Crowe, O. (2012) Irish Wetland Bird Survey: Waterbird Status and Distribution 2001/02 - 2009/09. BirdWatch Ireland, Kilcoole, Co. Wicklow.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The population estimate was derived by averaging peak annual winter counts for this species over a five year period. Partial or incomplete counts were excluded from the calculation of the mean estimate. This species is a relatively scarce winter visitor to Ireland (recorded at 14 sites during the 2004/05-2008/09 winter period) and is likely to be underrecorded. For further information refer to Crowe and Boland (2012).

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

(1977) The changing status and distribution of the Bewick’s Swan in Ireland. Irish Birds 1: 3-15.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Merne (1977) collated counts of Bewick's Swans in Ireland during the winter of 1975/76. He estimated the population at 2000 - 2250 individuals overwintering on the island of Ireland and presents count data amounting up to 1830 individuals at sites in the Republic. This latter figure is compared with the 2010 census to derive the long-term trend.
bird_report.measures_taken: Bewick’s Swan is a protected species in Ireland (Act 2.1); a number of SPAs have been designated for its conservation (Act 1.2). Annual monitoring of wetland sites occurs & Ireland participates in the five yearly International Swan Census (Act 6.1).

bird_report.population_additional_info: The population estimate was derived by averaging peak annual winter counts for this species over a five year period. Partial or incomplete counts were excluded from the calculation of the mean estimate. Given the species is a relatively scarce winter visitor to Ireland (recorded at 35 sites during the 2004/05-2008/09 winter period) and is likely to be underrecorded, the quality of the estimate is categroised as poor. For further information refer to Crowe and Boland (2012).

bird_report.population_sources: O'Donnell, A. (2012) Scarce migrants in Ireland, 2007 and 2008. Irish Birds 9: 421-446. Irish Birding Website: http://www.irishbirding.com.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The species is likely to be underrecorded and/or overlooked given it largely winters offshore, often associating with Common Scoter flocks and usually occurring within a few kilometres of the coast. The 2012 'Scarce Migrants in Ireland Report', details records for 30 birds seen in 2007 and 28 birds seen in 2008. Additional winter records are available on the Irish Birding Website whereby an average of 40 birds have been recorded each winter during the period 2008-2013.

bird_report.measures_taken: Velvet Scoter occurs in very low numbers off the coast of Ireland and is not on the hunting list. Records of occurrences are reported regularly though the Irish Wetland Bird Survey and other sources.

bird_report.measures_taken: Agri-environmental schemes are in operation in some breeding areas (Ob 2); the overwintering population is monitored by I-WeBS (Obs 8 & 9). Some ringing of Golden Plover occurs (Ob 11); and research into the breeding ecology was also carried out (Ob 13).

bird_report.population_additional_info: The population estimate is based on a mean of peak counts with imputation for the overwintering period of 2006/07 to 2010/11 that was collected as part of the Irish Wetland Bird Survey (I-WeBS). This estimate is to be treated as a conservative one on account of the relatively poorer I-WeBS coverage of some of the areas that this species is distributed over.

population_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Crowe, O. (2013) Calculations of short- and long-term trends of wintering waterbirds for Article 12 reporting. Unpublished note. Crowe, O. & Holt, C. (2013) Estimates of waterbird numbers wintering in Ireland, 2006/07 – 2010/11. Irish Birds 9:4.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using a bespoke trend programme for wintering waterbirds called UINDEX. No conclusive long-term trend could be derived from the available data (i.e. Sheppard, 1993). For further information on both the long-term and the short-term trend calculations refer to Crowe (2013).
bird_report.measures_taken: Conservation projects for Lapwing and other breeding waders are in operation (Obs 3-5 & 16); Anti-predator measures undertaken at various Lapwing breeding sites (Ob 12); the population is monitored by I-WeBS and other surveys (Ob 15).

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using a bespoke trend programme for wintering waterbirds called UINDEX. The long-term trend was derived from an analyses of data from Sheppard (1993) and Crowe & Holt (2013). For further information on both the long-term and the short-term trend calculations refer to Crowe (2013).

bird_report.population_additional_info: The population estimate is based on the Irish data collected as part of the international spring count of the Greenland White-fronted population that winters in Ireland and Britain. This estimate does not include those individuals that primarily overwinter in Northern Ireland (i.e. the Lough McNean flock).

population_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

Unpublished Report. Fox, T. and Francis, I. (1999) Report of the 1998/999 National Census of Greenland White-fronted Geese in Britain. Department of Wildlife Ecology National Environmental Research Institute, Denmark. 8 p.; http://gwfg-conservation.wikispaces.com/file/view/Greenland%20White-fronted%20Geese%20in%20Britain%201998-99.doc/166656431/Greenland%20White-fronted%20Geese%20in%20Britain%201998-99.doc. bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Burke, B., Egan, F., Wilson. H.J., Norriss, D. and Walsh, A. (in prep) A review of the Greenland White-fronted Geese in Ireland 1982/83 – 2011/12. Unpublished Report. Fox, T., Francis, I. and Walsh, A. (2012) Report of the 2011/2012 International Census of Greenland White-fronted Geese.Greenland White-fronted Goose Study. 28 p.; http://gwfg-conservation.wikispaces.com/file/view/Greenland%20White-fronted%20Geese%20in%20Britain%20%26%20Ireland%202011-12.pdf/367349050/Greenland%20White-fronted%20Geese%20in%20Britain%20%26%20Ireland%202011-12.pdf. Fox, T., Norriss, D.W., Stroud, D.A., Wilson, H.J. (1994) Greenland White-fronted geese in Ireland and Britain 1982/83-1993/94. Greenland White-fronted Goose Study/National Parks and Wildlife Service, Aberystwyth and Dublin, 54 pp.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The methodology of counting all flocks within a given period of a few consecutive days in spring was the same in both spring 1999 and 2012. The Irish population estimate for spring 1999 was 13,575 geese – comprising 8,958 birds counted on international spring census dates at Wexford, and 4,617 geese counted in the rest of Ireland. The count used for the Lough McNean flock (68 geese occuring in Northern Ireland) was subtracted from the overall Irish total resulting in an estimate of 13,507 geese in the Republic of Ireland. Data from the 1983 spring census was used to inform the long-term population trend. Excluding those flocks that primarily overwinter in Northern Ireland the 1983 population estimate was 9098 individuals (see Fox et al 1994).
bird_report.measures_taken: Legislation enacted (Ob 3.5); agri-environment schemes in operation (Obs 4.1, 7, & 8); mark/re-sighting study maintained (Obs 5.2.1 & 9); annual census work maintained (Ob 5.3); SPA Network complete (Ob 6); and scientific research supported (Obs 5 & 9).

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using a bespoke trend programme for wintering waterbirds called UINDEX. The long-term trend was derived from an analyses of data from Sheppard (1993) and Crowe & Holt (2013).
bird_report.measures_taken: The SPA Network for this species is now complete (Ob 5); the overwintering population is monitored by the Irish Wetland Bird Survey (Ob 9); bird ringing activities supported (Ob 10); and ecological research is supported (Ob 11).

bird_report.population_sources: Irish Wetland Bird Survey unpublished data from O. Crowe; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: This species along with other gull species that overwinter in Ireland is currently only poorly covered by the Irish Wetland Bird Survey (I-WeBS) programme. This reported population size, which is an underestimate of the true population size, is based on the mean of peaks for the 2006/07-2010/11 period.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Irish Wetland Bird Survey unpublished data from O. Crowe; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Hutchinson, C. (1979) Ireland's Wetlands and their Birds. Irish Wildbird Conservancy.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The Irish Wetland Bird Survey only provides partial data on this and other wintering gull species. Furthermore only limited historical data exists for this group of birds (see Hutchinson 1979). Therefore due to the insufficiency of data no conclusive determination can be made on both the short- and the long-term trends.

bird_report.population_additional_info: The population estimate is based on a mean of peak counts with imputation for the overwintering period of 2006/07 to 2010/11 that was collected as part of the Irish Wetland Bird Survey (I-WeBS). This estimate is to be treated as a conservative one on account of the relatively poorer I-WeBS coverage of some of the areas that this species is distributed over.

(2013) Estimates of waterbird numbers wintering in Ireland, 2006/07 – 2010/11. Irish Birds 9:4. Sheppard, R. (1993) Ireland's Wetland Wealth. Irish Wildbird Conservancy.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using a bespoke trend programme for wintering waterbirds called UINDEX. The long-term trend was derived from an analyses of data from Sheppard (1993) and Crowe & Holt (2013). For further information on both the long-term and the short-term trend calculations refer to Crowe (2013).

bird_report.measures_taken: Curlew removed from the hunting list (Ob 1); a conservation project is active (Obs 2 & 3); the SPA Network is complete and wildfowl sanctuaries are in place (Obs 5 & 8); the population is monitored by I-WeBS (Ob 9); and ringing is supported (Ob 10).
bird_report.further_information:
Removal of Curlew from the hunting list: http://www.npws.ie/news/name,14380,en.html.
Breeding Curlew conservation work - HELP Project: http://www.rspb.org.uk/ourwork/projects/details/282973-halting-environmental-loss-project#objectives.
Special Protection Areas for Curlew: http://www.npws.ie/protectedsites/specialprotectionareasspa/.
Irish Wildfowl sanctuaries: http://www.npws.ie/protectedsites/wildfowlsanctuaries/.
Irish Wetland Bird Survey (I-WeBS): Boland, H. & Crowe, O. (2012) Irish Wetland Bird Survey: Waterbird Status and Distribution 2001/02 - 2008/09. BirdWatch Ireland Kilkoole, Co Wicklow. http://www.birdwatchireland.ie/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=y06hHCtXkyc=&tabid=281.; Bird
Ringing and marking: Merne, O. (2011) Irish Ringing Report 2009. Irish Birds 9: 315-326.

bird_report.measures_taken: All main breeding colonies are designated as SPAs (Ob 2.1.1). These colonies are subject to on-going conservation projects with dedicated wardens managing the sites and monitoring (including ringing) the breeding birds (Obs 2.2 & 3.1).

bird_report.population_sources: Crowe, O., Musgrove, A.J. & O'Halloran, J. (2014). Generating population estimates for common and widespread breeding birds in Ireland. Bird Study 61 (1) 82 - 90. Expert opinion: J. Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie. Hardey, J., Crick, H.Q.P., Wernham, C.V., Riley, H. & Thompson, D.B.A. (2009) Raptors: a field guide for survey and monitoring. 2nd Edition. The Stationery Office, Edinburgh.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Hardey et al. (2009) estimated the population at 8,600 breeding pairs which is largely based on expert opinion. Crowe et al. (2014) provides a more robust estimate of population size (in individuals) which was generated using a combination of Countryside Bird Survey data and recent breeding Bird Atlas data (see Crowe et al 2014). The quality of assessment is listed as moderate, as detection rates for Sparrowhawk are likely to be low based on the methods employed for multi-species surveys.

population_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Crowe O. (2013) Calculation of short-term trends for Common and Widespread Breeding Birds for Article 12 Reporting. Unpublished report.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Absent data

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser. Expert opinion: J. Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). Although a recorded 22% decline was produced this was not statistically significant. Comprehensive historical population data does not exist for this species in Ireland. The long-term change in breeding range indicates stability (see section 5) but without data on historical and current breeding densities the long-term population trend is reported here as an unknown.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Expert opinion: J. Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the abundance of occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2007-11 breeding bird atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with those of the 1988-91 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al 1993). The long-term range trend calculation was based on a comparison with the 1968-72 breeding atlas (Sharrock 1976) using the same criteria and resulted in a calculated decrease of 2%. This is a relatively small decrease and it was considered more appropriate to report the long-term trend as a stable one. The quality of both these estimates of range change are listed as moderate due to the likely low and variable detection rates of Sparrowhawk.

population_type_of_estimate.desc: The best available single figure or range

bird_report.population_sources: Rooney, E. (2013) Ecology and breeding biology of the Common Buzzard Buteo buteo in Ireland. PhD Thesis, School of Biological Sciences, Queens Univeristy Belfast. Clements, R. (2002) The Common buzzard in Britain: A new population estimate. British Birds 95: 377-383. Expert opinion - J. Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Rooney (2013) estimated the population size of Buzzards in Ireland, by modelling the core range of the breeding population using distribution data from the recent bird atlas (Balmer et al 2013) combined with density data from specific surveys. In addition to the core range, in recently colonised areas a density of 20 pairs of Buzzards per 10km2 was used, as estimated by Clements (2000) during early expansion in Britain. This produced an estimate of 3,312 breeding pairs for all Ireland, with approximately 1,500 pairs in the Republic of Ireland.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Norriss (1991) presents population figures for this species which was just starting to recolonize this country. For the period 1980-82 he reported the known breeding population at just 4 pairs and for the period 1989-91 the known population had risen to 26 pairs. Norriss (1991) acknowledges that these estimates are based on an incomplete survey and are likely to have underestimated the true population.

bird_report.population_additional_info: The Barn Owl population estimate is based on data from specific density survey work which produced an overall density estimate of 1.8 breeding sites per 10 km2 (Lusby et al., 2009a; 2009b; 2010; 2012; O’Clery et al., 2012). Incorporating this density estimate with the estimated breeding range for this species (see section 4) a population estimate of 400 – 500 pairs is produced.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Expert opinion: J.Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: During the period 1995 - 1997, survey work recorded 84 Barn Owl nest and roost sites throughout the country. All sites were re-visited in 2008 – 2013. Of the original sites, 56 were lost over the 13 – 15 year period, which indicates a short term decline of 67%. The quality of assessment is listed as moderate as although Barn Owls are generally sedentary and have a high site fidelity, breeding pairs can relocate nest sites within territories. Although efforts were made to locate alternative active sites within the same territories, new sites which were not recorded may cause an overestimation of the short-term population decline. Comprehensive historical population data does not exist for this species in Ireland. The long-term change in breeding range indicates a significant decline in breeding range (see section 5) and so it is likely that the population has also declined in the long-term but without data on historical breeding densities the magnitude of the long-term population decline is not reported here. Therefore the long-term population trend has to be reported as 'unknown'.

range_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

British Trust for Ornithology. Expert opinion: J.Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Comparing the number of 10km squares with contemporary proven breeding records (confirmed and probable) with those from Sharrock (1976) a 56% long-term population decline is recorded. Applying the same criteria to those records as reported by Gibbons et al (1993) a 117% increase is calculated. A recorded short-term breeding range increase of 76% is calculated using all breeding records. This value is considered more appropriate to report here but should be used with caution as it is also an overestimate due to the increase in monitoring of Barn Owls in recent years. As it runs contrary to the short-term population trend assessment, the quality of the short-term range trend estimate is considered to be poor.

National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht, Dublin, Ireland; http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM59.pdf.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Based on a 2010 national survey Ruddock et al. (2012) estimated the population to be 128 to 172 breeding pairs. Very low rates of polygyny were observed (<1%) and therefore this reported figure corresponds to an estimate of breeding females occurring in Ireland in 2010.

National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht, Dublin, Ireland; http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM59.pdf. Norriss, D.W., Marsh, J., McMahon, D. & Oliver, G.A. (2002) A national survey of breeding Hen Harriers Circus cyaneus in Ireland 1998-2000. Irish Birds 7: 1-12. Expert opinion: John Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Ruddock, M., Dunlop, B.J., O’Toole, L., Mee, A. & Nagle, T. (2012) Republic of Ireland National Hen Harrier Survey 2010. Irish Wildlife Manual, No. 59. National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht, Dublin, Ireland; http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM59.pdf. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: A direct comparison of the population estimates from the first (1998 - 2000) and third (2010) national Hen Harrier surveys indicates a population increase of 25 - 33%. However the recorded survey effort for the 2010 national survey was substantially greater compared with the first national survey. In order to control for survey effort a subsample of 84 10km survey squares which were covered during both surveys was interrogated to derive a short term population trend. In 1998 – 2000 a total of 110 - 152 possible pairs were recorded within the 84 survey squares. When this is compared with the 98 - 131 pairs from the 2010 survey a decline of 11 – 14% is calculated. Although this estimated population trend is considered more robust than that estimate derived from the straight comparison of the national population estimates it should be treated with caution. Based largely on expert opinion, the all-Ireland population estimate for the early 1970's was reported in Sharrock (1976) as 200 - 300 pairs. Assuming similar changes occurred at the all-Ireland and the national level by using the mid-points of the aforementioned ranges an approximate long-term population trend can be calculated by comparing the historical population estimate with the 2010 all-Ireland population estimate of 158-205 pairs. This results in an estimated population decline of 27%.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Ruddock, M., Dunlop, B.J., O’Toole, L., Mee, A. & Nagle, T. (2012) Republic of Ireland National Hen Harrier Survey 2010. Irish Wildlife Manual, No. 59. National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht, Dublin, Ireland; http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM59.pdf.http://www.npws.ie/publications/irishwildlifemanuals/IWM59.pdf. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: A direct comparison of the number of 10km squares that held confirmed or possible breeding Hen Harrier records from the first and third national Hen Harrier surveys indicates a range increase of 17%. However the recorded survey effort for the third national survey in 2010 was substantially greater than the first national survey (1998-2000). In order to control for survey effort, a subsample of 84 10km survey squares which were covered during both surveys was interrogated to derive a short term range trend. In 1998 – 2000 a total of 49 10km survey squares held confirmed or possible breeding records compared to 46 10km squares in 2010. This equates to a 6% range decrease. Although this estimated breeding range trend is considered more robust than an estimate derived from a straight comparison of the total number of 10kms squares with breeding records from each survey it should be treated with caution. In order to derive a long-term range trend it was considered more appropriate to compare the range recorded during the breeding atlas period of 1968 – 72 of Sharrock (1976) with the breeding distribution data from the most recent breeding bird atlas (i.e. 2008 – 11) of Balmer et al (2013) as opposed to using the 2010 national survey data only as the atlases were conducted over several breeding seasons by several volunteers. A comparison of the numbers of all breeding records (which includes possible breeding records) between the period 1968 – 1972 to 2008 – 2011 (169 vs. 142 10km squares) indicates a 16% decline in the long-term breeding range trend.
