bird_report.population_additional_info: To date there has been no systematic national survey undertaken for Merlin. Based largely on expert opinion, Hardy et al (2009) estimated the population at 200 – 400 pairs. Cognisant of the recent population estimate of 32 pairs for Northern Ireland (Ewing et al 2011) and also informed by the recent bird atlas (Balmer et al 2013) it is considered that Hardy et al’s (2009) estimate is the most suitable population estimate to be reported here.

The available data to hand are principally the 1968-72 and 1988-91 breeding bird atlases (Sharrock 1976 and Gibbons et al 1993). Such data is primarily focussed on the species’ distribution and so no short- or long-term population trends could be estimated.

The quality of this distribution and range map is considered to be moderate at best due to the fact that Balmer et al's (2013) distribution of proven records may underestimate the true distribution of this secretive breeding species.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The breeding bird atlas of 2007 – 11 recorded 50 10km squares with proven (confirmed or probable) records (Balmer et al 2013). Gibbons et al. (1993) recorded proven breeding in a total of 40 10km squares. This represents a short term range increase of 25%. Sharrock (1976) recorded proven breeding in a total of 88 10km squares. This represents a long-term range decrease of 43%. Due to a combination of the difficulties in detecting Merlin, acquiring evidence of breeding and differences in survey effort between the atlases both the short- and the long-term range trend estimates should be treated with caution.

(2012) A Report on the breeding survey of the Peregrine Falcon (Falco peregrinus) in the North West Region of Ireland in 2012. Unpublished report, NPWS. Expert opinion: J. Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The third and most recent survey of breeding Peregrine in the Republic of Ireland was undertaken in 2002, which estimated 390 occupied breeding territories (Madden et al., 2009). Recent evidence has suggested that the population has increased since 2002 (See Balmer et al 2013, Burke 2012, O’Brien 2013 and expert opinion J Lusby). In the absence of a national survey a contemporary national population estimate was derived by extrapolating from the recorded increase in breeding territories at study sites located in counties Mayo, Sligo and Wicklow) which were also survyed as part of the 2002 national survey. The Peregrine population is estimated to have increased by 32% since 2002 at these study sites. Applying this increase to the 2002 national population estimate a contemporary population estimate of 515 occupied territories is calculated.

Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: As per section 2.8 the last national survey of Peregrine in Ireland was undertaken in 2002 (Madden et al 2009). An analysis of on-going population monitoring in counties Mayo, Sligo and Wicklow was undertaken and an increase of 32% in breeding territories since the 2002 national census is estimated (Burke, 2012, O’Brien 2013 and J. Lusby - expert opinion). The long-term population trend was calculated comparing the contemporary population estimate with Norriss and Wilson’s (1983) estimate of 225 breeding territories as recorded during the first national Peregrine survey of 1981.

Expert opinion: J. Lusby, Birdwatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie. Hardey, J., Crick, H.Q.P., Wernham, C.V., Riley, H. & Thompson, D.B.A. 2009. Raptors: a field guide for survey and monitoring. 2nd Edition. The Stationery Office, Edinburgh.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Hardey et al. (2009) estimated the population at 8,400 breeding pairs which is largely based on expert opinion. Crowe et al. (2014) provides a more robust estimate of population size (in individuals) which was generated using a combination of Countryside Bird Survey data and recent breeding Bird Atlas data (see Crowe et al 2014). The quality of assessment is listed as moderate, as detection rates for Kestrel are likely to be low based on the methods employed for multi-species surveys.

population_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The atlas of breeding birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & A.D. Poyser. Expert opinion: J. Lusby, Birdwatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The short-term population trend for this species, which is monitored by the Countryside Bird Survey (CBS), was calculated using a log-linear model with Poisson error terms using the freeware program TRIM (Trends and Indices for Monitoring Data, see Crowe 2013 for further information). Although a recorded 21% decline was produced this was not statistically significant. Comprehensive historical population data does not exist for this species in Ireland. The long-term change in breeding range indicates a decline (see section 5) but without data on historical and current breeding densities the long-term population trend is reported here as an unknown.

British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser.

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was initially calculated by comparing the abundance of proven (i.e. confirmed and probable) 10km squares from the 2007-11 breeding bird atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with those of the 1988-91 breeding brid atlas (Gibbons et al 1993). This represents a short term range increase of 54% in proven breeding records. However it was considered more appropriate to report on the change in range by analysing all records (i.e. confirmed probable and possible records). This results in a calculated increase of 13%. This estimate should be used with caution as differences in survey effort between these two atlases may have resulted in an overestimation of the true trend. The 1968-72 breeding bird atlas (Sharrock 1976) recorded confirmed or probable breeding for Kestrel in 676 10km survey squares, which represents a long term range decrease of 29%. Using all breeding records (n=810), the magnitude of the decline was 5%. The quality of both these estimates is listed as moderate because of potential for variation in surveyor effort between the atlas surveys.

(2012) The Duhallow Raptor Conservation Project; Interim Report 2012. Unpublished report by BirdWatch Ireland. Expert opinion: J. Lusby, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: To date there has been no systematic national survey of the Long-eared Owl population in Ireland. The only specific survey work to determine breeding densities of Long-eared Owl in Ireland was undertaken over 600km2 at two separate study sites in 2012. This work produced an estimated density of 2.8 – 5.1 pairs per 10km2 (Lusby et al., 2012; O’Clery et al., 2012). The breeding range map (see section 4) is considered to be a truer reflection of Long-eared Owl distribution compared with that generated solely by the recent breeding bird atlas (Balmer et al. 2013), due to low detection rates for Long-eared Owl in the breeding atlases. By multiplying the range with the estimated breeding density a population estimate of 1,484 - 2,703 breeding pairs is produced. This reported estimate corresponds reasonably with the estimate of 1,500 to 2,000 pairs as reported by Hardy et al (2009).

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Balmer et al (2013) recorded confirmed or probable breeding for Long-eared Owl in 277 10km survey squares in the Republic of Ireland for the period 2008-2011. Gibbons et al recorded a total of 119 confirmed or probable 10km squares. This amounts to a short term range increase of some 133%. This estimate must be treated with caution as it is very likely to be an overestimate due to differences in survey effort between the atlases. Applying the same criteria to the 1968-72 breeding bird atlas (Sharrock 1976), a long term range increase of 44% is arrived at. This is also likely to be an overestimate of the true situation due to differences in survey effort between the atlases.

population_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_sources: Mitchell, P. Ian, Newton, S.F., Ratcliffe, N. & Dunn, T.E. (2004) Seabird populations of Britain and Ireland. Results of the Seabird 2000 Census (1998-2002). T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The last national population estimate for this species was based on the Seabird 2000 Census (see Mitchell et al 2004). Since then approximately 52% of the then estimated population from 19 colonies has been monitored. An analysis of this subsample shows an overall decline. Extrapolating this decline a contemporary population estimate of 31,930 pairs is produced.

population_trend_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_sources: Mitchell, P. Ian, Newton, S.F., Ratcliffe, N. & Dunn, T.E. (2004) Seabird populations of Britain and Ireland. Results of the Seabird 2000 Census (1998-2002). T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.

population_trend_long_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Lloyd, C., Tasker, M.L. & Partridge, K. (1991) The Status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished seabird data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: A calculated decrease of 3.2% is estimated for the short-term period (see Section 2.8). However this is a relatively small decrease (i.e. <5%) and therefore it is considered more appropriate to report the short-term trend as being stable.The long-term population trend is approximated by comparing the population estimate as described by Lloyd et al (1991), which is based on survey data primarily collected during the period 1985 – 1987, with the contemporary population estimate.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: The species distribution map was based on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map. As this is a marine cliff nesting species only those range cells that intersected the coast were retained in the final map.

range_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Mitchell, P. Ian, Newton, S.F., Ratcliffe, N. & Dunn, T.E. (2004) Seabird populations of Britain and Ireland. Results of the Seabird 2000 Census (1998-2002). T & AD Poyser, London.

range_trend_long_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser. Lloyd, C., Tasker, M.L. & Partridge, K. (1991) The status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was estimated by comparing the number of 10km squares containing proven records (i.e. confirmed and probable) from the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with the findings of the Seabird 2000 Census which was primarily undertaken during the period 1998 - 2002 (Mitchell et al 2004). Lloyd et al (1991) summarises the breeding seabird data collected during the period 1985-87 as part of the Seabird Colony Register (SCR). As part of the second breeding bird atlas Gibbons et al (1993) incorporated the SCR distribution data into the atlas dataset and added further data to produce distribution maps. The long-term trend reported here compares the numbers of 10km squares containing proven records as presented in Gibbons et al (1993) with those of Balmer et al (2013) which describes the range trend from the period 1985-91 to 2008-11.

T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Ireland now has six Gannet colonies which is an increase of one since the Seabird 2000 Census. Mitchell et al (2004) provides a population estimate for the period 1998-2002. Two colonies have been monitored in during the reporting period and the recorded increase in the population estimates at these colonies form the basis for deriving a contemporary national population estimate. This estimate attempts to take into account the likely differential growth rates at the various colonies.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Published data indicates that this species only started to breed in Ireland in 2002 (Mitchell et al 2004, Perry 2013) therefore only the short-term trend can be reported on.

T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The last national population estimate for this species was based on the Seabird 2000 Census (see Mitchell et al 2004). Between 2010 and 2012 approximately 32% of the then estimated population from five colonies has been monitored during the intervening period. An analysis of this subsample shows an overall increase. Extrapolating this increase a contemporary population estimate of 1,927 pairs is produced.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Hutchinson, C.D. (1989) Birds in Ireland. Irish Wildbird Conservancy.Cramp, S, Bourne, W.R. P.& Saunders, D. (1974). The Seabirds of Britain and Ireland. London. Whilde, A. (1984) Some aspects of the ecology of a small colony of Common gulls. Irish Birds 2:466 - 471.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: An approximate short-term population trend is produced by comparing the population estimate as noted in Mitchell et al (2004) with the contemporary population estimate (see Section 2.8). The long-term population trend is approximated by comparing the population estimate as outlined by Hutchinson (1989), which is based on the survey data of Cramp et al (1974) and Whilde (1984) and spans the period 1969 - 1978.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: The species distribution map was based on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map. This gull breeds on both marine and inland islands; to improve its accuracy the range was modified by removing those inland 10km squares (i.e. those squares that do not intersect the coastline) which did not contain breeding records from the final range map.

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser. Lloyd, C., Tasker, M.L. & Partridge, K. (1991) The status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was estimated by comparing the number of 10km squares containing proven records (i.e. confirmed and probable) from the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with the findings of the Seabird 2000 Census which was primarily undertaken during the period 1998 - 2002 (Mitchell et al 2004). The recorded short-term range increase may well be an overestimate due to the greater survey effort at inland sites undertaken as part of the 2007 -11 Bird Atlas when compared with the Seabird 2000 Census. Lloyd et al (1991) summarises the breeding seabird data collected during the period 1985-87 as part of the Seabird Colony Register (SCR). As part of the second breeding bird atlas Gibbons et al (1993) incorporated the SCR distribution data into the atlas dataset and added further data to produce distribution maps. The long-term trend reported here compares the numbers of 10km squares containing proven records as presented in Gibbons et al (1993) with those of Balmer et al (2013) which describes the range trend from the period 1985-91 to 2008-11.
bird_report.measures_taken: Common Gull is not on the Open Seasons Order and data on licenses given to cull individuals are available but none were issued for 2008-12 (Ob 1); this species is listed for several SPAs (Ob 2); I-WeBS gives data on the wintering population (Ob 5).

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Lloyd, C., Tasker, M.L. & Partridge, K. (1991) The status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: An approximate short-term population trend is produced by comparing the population estimate as noted in Mitchell et al (2004) with the contemporary population estimate (see Section 2.8). The long-term population trend is approximated by comparing the population estimate as described by Lloyd et al (1991), which is based on survey data primarily collected during the period 1985 – 1987, with the contemporary population estimate. This calulated long-term population trend may underestimate the actual overall decline due to the fact that inland gull colonies were only partially covered during the period 1985-1987. Lloyd et al (1991) gives an all-Ireland population estimate of 44,700 pairs. In order to approximate the population for the Republic the main Northern Irish colonies of Raithlin Island, Copeland Island, Gun's Island and Burial Island were subtracted for the all-Ireland population estimate.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.population_additional_info: The last national population estimate for this species was based on the Seabird 2000 Census (see Mitchell et al 2004). The three largest Sandwich Tern colonies are monitored on a near annual basis. Assuming no significant changes occurred to the numbers of breeding birds occurring at the smaller colonies since 2002 a national population estimate of 2,727 pairs is estimated.

bird_report.range_additional_info: The species distribution map was based on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map. This gull breeds on both marine and inland islands; to improve its accuracy the range was modified by removing those inland 10km squares (i.e. those squares that do not intersect the coastline) which did not contain breeding records from the final range map.

The long-term range trend is based on a comparison of the 2007-11 Bird Atlas and the findings of the 1984 All-Ireland Tern Survey (Balmer et al 2013; Whilde 1985).

bird_report.population_additional_info: The last national population estimate for this species was based on the Seabird 2000 Census (see Mitchell et al 2004). The three largest east coast Common Tern colonies are monitored on a near annual basis. Additionally two inland sites were surveyed during the period 2006-2007. Assuming no significant changes occurred to the numbers of breeding birds occurring at these two inland sites since 2007 and assuming no significant changes occurred at the unmonitored colonies since 2002 a national population estimate of 4,740 pairs can be calculated.

T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The last national population estimate for this species was based on the Seabird 2000 Census (see Mitchell et al 2004). Since then approximately 87% of the then estimated population from 10 colonies has been monitored. An analysis of this subsample shows an overall decline of 7.0%. Extrapolating this decline a contemporary population estimate of 25,525 individuals is produced.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: An approximate short-term population trend is produced by comparing the population estimate as noted in Mitchell et al (2004) with the contemporary population estimate (see Section 2.8). The long-term population trend is approximated by comparing the population estimate as described by Lloyd et al (1991), which is based on survey data primarily collected during the period 1985 – 1987, with the contemporary population estimate.

bird_report.range_additional_info: The species distribution map was based on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map. As this is a marine cliff nesting species only those range cells that intersected the coast were retained in the final map.

range_trend_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Mitchell, P. Ian, Newton, S.F., Ratcliffe, N. & Dunn, T.E. (2004) Seabird populations of Britain and Ireland. Results of the Seabird 2000 Census (1998-2002). T & AD Poyser, London.

range_trend_long_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser. Lloyd, C., Tasker, M.L. & Partridge, K. (1991) The status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was estimated by comparing the number of 10km squares containing proven records (i.e. confirmed and probable) from the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with the findings of the Seabird 2000 Census which was primarily undertaken during the period 1998 - 2002 (Mitchell et al 2004). Lloyd et al (1991) summarises the breeding seabird data collected during the period 1985-87 as part of the Seabird Colony Register (SCR). As part of the second breeding bird atlas Gibbons et al (1993) incorporated the SCR distribution data into the atlas dataset and added further data to produce distribution maps. The long-term trend reported here compares the numbers of 10km squares containing proven records as presented in Gibbons et al (1993) with those of Balmer et al (2013) which describes the range trend from the period 1985-91 to 2008-11.

bird_report.population_additional_info: The first and last robust national population estimate for this species was based on the Seabird 2000 Census (see Mitchell et al 2004). Due to an insufficiency of recent data it was not possible to report a more contemporary population estimate.

As this is a coastal nesting species only those range cells that intersected the coast were retained in the final map.

British Trust for Ornithology. Mitchell, P. Ian, Newton, S.F., Ratcliffe, N. & Dunn, T.E. (2004) Seabird populations of Britain and Ireland. Results of the Seabird 2000 Census (1998-2002). bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser. Lloyd, C., Tasker, M.L. & Partridge, K. (1991) The status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was estimated by comparing the number of 10km squares containing proven records (i.e. confirmed and probable) from the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with the findings of the Seabird 2000 Census which was primarily undertaken during the period 1998 - 2002 (Mitchell et al 2004). Lloyd et al (1991) summarises the breeding seabird data collected during the period 1985-87 as part of the Seabird Colony Register (SCR). As part of the second breeding bird atlas Gibbons et al (1993) incorporated the SCR distribution data into the atlas dataset and added further data to produce distribution maps. The long-term trend reported here compares the numbers of 10km squares containing proven records as presented in Gibbons et al (1993) with those of Balmer et al (2013) which describes the range trend from the period 1985-91 to 2008-11.

population_type_of_estimate.desc: The best available single figure or range

population_method.desc: Estimate based on partial data with some extrapolation and/or modelling

bird_report.population_sources: Mitchell, P. Ian, Newton, S.F., Ratcliffe, N. & Dunn, T.E. (2004) Seabird populations of Britain and Ireland. Results of the Seabird 2000 Census (1998-2002). T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: No robust systematic survey of this burrow nesting species has been undertaken in Ireland. The last national population estimate for this species was based on the Seabird 2000 Census (see Mitchell et al 2004). Since then approximately 51% of the then estimated population from five colonies has been monitored. An analysis of this subsample shows an overall increase of 8.0%. Extrapolating this increase a contemporary population estimate of 21,212 individuals is produced.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: An approximate short-term population trend is produced by comparing the population estimate as noted in Mitchell et al (2004) with the contemporary population estimate (see Section 2.8). The long-term population trend is approximated by comparing the population estimate as described by Lloyd et al (1991), which is based on survey data primarily collected during the period 1985 – 1987, with the contemporary population estimate.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: A calculated increase of 3.4% is estimated for the short-term period (see Section 2.8). However this is a relatively small increase (i.e. <5%) and therefore it is considered more appropriate to report the short-term trend as being stable. The long-term population trend is approximated by comparing the population estimate as described by Lloyd et al (1991), which is based on survey data primarily collected during the period 1985 – 1987, with the contemporary population estimate.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: An approximate short-term population trend is produced by comparing the population estimate as noted in Mitchell et al (2004) with the contemporary population estimate (see Section 2.8). The long-term population trend is approximated by comparing the population estimate as described by Lloyd et al (1991), which is based on survey data primarily collected during the period 1985 – 1987, with the contemporary population estimate. The long-term population trend should be regarded as an overestimate due to the fact that inland gull colonies were only partially covered during the period 1985-1987.

bird_report.range_additional_info: The species distribution map was based on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map. This gull breeds on coastal headlands and both marine and inland islands; to improve its accuracy the range was modified by removing those inland 10km squares (i.e. those squares that do not intersect the coastline) which did not contain breeding records from the final range map.

T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The last national population estimate for this species was based on the Seabird 2000 Census (see Mitchell et al 2004). Since then approximately 59% of the then estimated population from 13 colonies has been monitored. An analysis of this subsample shows an overall decline. Extrapolating this decline a contemporary population estimate of 4,366 pairs is produced.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Lloyd, C., Tasker, M.L. & Partridge, K. (1991) The status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London. Expert opinion and unpublished data: S. Newton, BirdWatch Ireland; http://www.birdwatchireland.ie.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: A calculated decrease of 4% is estimated for the short-term period (see Section 2.8). However this is a relatively small decrease (i.e. <5%) and therefore it is considered more appropriate to report the short-term trend as being stable. The long-term population trend is approximated by comparing the population estimate as described by Lloyd et al (1991), which is based on survey data primarily collected during the period 1985 – 1987, with the contemporary population estimate.

range_method.desc: Complete survey or a statistically robust estimate

bird_report.range_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology.
bird_report.range_additional_info: The species distribution map was based on confirmed and probable breeding records from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the recommended Range Tool was applied to generate the range map. This is a predominatly coastal breeding species but some inland colonies exist therefore to imporve the accurancy of the range those inland range sqaures (i.e. do not interesct the coast) that did not hold breeding records were removed from the final map.

British Trust for Ornithology. Mitchell, P. Ian, Newton, S.F., Ratcliffe, N. & Dunn, T.E. (2004) Seabird populations of Britain and Ireland. Results of the Seabird 2000 Census (1998-2002). bird_report.range_trend_long_sources: Balmer, D., Gillings, S., Caffrey, B., Swan, B., Downie, I. & Fuller, R. (2013) Bird Atlas 2007-11 The breeding and wintering birds of Britain and Ireland. British Trust for Ornithology. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser. Lloyd, C., Tasker, M.L. & Partridge, K. (1991) The status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was estimated by comparing the number of 10km squares containing proven records (i.e. confirmed and probable) from the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with the findings of the Seabird 2000 Census which was primarily undertaken during the period 1998 - 2002 (Mitchell et al 2004). The recorded short-term range increase may well be an overestimate due to the greater survey effort at inland sites undertaken as part of the 2007-11 Bird Atlas when compared with the Seabird 2000 Census. Lloyd et al (1991) summarises the breeding seabird data collected during the period 1985-87 as part of the Seabird Colony Register (SCR). As part of the second breeding bird atlas Gibbons et al (1993) incorporated the SCR distribution data into the atlas dataset and added further data to produce distribution maps. The long-term trend reported here compares the numbers of 10km squares containing proven records as presented in Gibbons et al (1993) with those of Balmer et al (2013) which describes the range trend from the period 1985-91 to 2008-11.

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was estimated by comparing the number of 10km squares containing proven records (i.e. confirmed and probable) of the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with the findings of the Seabird 2000 Census which was primarily undertaken during the period 1998 - 2002 (Mitchell et al 2004). Lloyd et al (1991) summarises the breeding seabird data collected during the period 1985-87 as part of the Seabird Colony Register (SCR). As part of the second breeding bird atlas Gibbons et al (1993) incorporated the SCR distribution data into the atlas dataset and added further data to produce distribution maps. The long-term trend reported here compares the numbers of 10km squares containing proven records as presented in Gibbons et al (1993) with those of Balmer et (2013) which describes the range trend from the period 1985-91 to 2008-11. These estimated declines may be overestimates due to the difficulties involved in recording breeding evidence for this species as part of an atlas project compared to dedicated seabird surveys which informed both the 1985 - 1991 and the 1998 - 2002 datasets.

bird_report.measures_taken: All main breeding colonies are designated as SPAs (Ob 2.1.1). These colonies are subject to on-going conservation projects with dedicated wardens managing the sites and monitoring (including ringing) the breeding birds (Obs 2.2 & 3.1).

(1991) The status of Seabirds in Britain and Ireland. T & AD Poyser, London.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: The short-term range trend was estimated by comparing the number of 10km squares containing proven records (i.e. confirmed and probable) from the 2007-11 Bird Atlas (Balmer et al 2013) with the findings of the Seabird 2000 Census which was primarily undertaken during the period 1998 - 2002 (Mitchell et al 2004). The recorded short-term range increase may well be an overestimate due to the greater survey effort at inland undertaken as part of the 2007-11 Bird Atlas when compared with the Seabird 2000 Census. Lloyd et al (1991) summarises the breeding seabird data collected during the period 1985-87 as part of the Seabird Colony Register (SCR). As part of the second breeding bird atlas Gibbons et al (1993) incorporated the SCR distribution data into the atlas dataset and added further data to produce distribution maps. The long-term trend reported here compares the numbers of 10km squares containing proven records as presented in Gibbons et al (1993) with those of Balmer et al (2013) which describes the range trend from the period 1985-91 to 2008-11.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: O’Meara M (1979) Distribution and numbers of Corncrakes in Ireland in 1978. Irish Birds 1: 382-405 National Parks & Wildlife Service Survey Data. This species is subject to annual monitoring through a national census co-ordinated by NPWS.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
Population Survey 1978 = 920 cmales Five-year-mean 1997-2001 = 151 cmales Five-year-mean 2008-2012 = 135 cmales
Per year, starting 1997, finishing 2012: 148, 152, 155, 148, 154, 139, 131, 145, 162, 162, 149, 146, 128, 133, 135, 132
The national population is split with two trends: 1) a decrease to a nadir in the Shannon Callows (due mainly to summer floods) and 2) a recent strengthening of numbers on offshore islands.

bird_report.range_additional_info: Once-off (i.e. in one year only) records of calling males in sites far removed from the definite range (in 10k squares O25, M48, M33 and V54) are not considered in the range/distribution map as expert opinion suggests that they would have been unlikely to have found mates in these outlying areas (no breeding was confirmed in these squares in any case).

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info:
The short-term range trend was calculated by comparing the amount of relevant occupied (i.e. confirmed, probable and possible) 10km squares from the 2012 National Corncrake Survey with those of the 2000 National Corncrake Survey.
The long-term range trend calculation was based on the 1978 survey published by O'Meara (1979) using the same criteria.
bird_report.further_information:
Agri-environment schemes, grant schemes to benefit Corncrake, introduction of Special Protection Areas, Annual monitoring, Corncrake Species Action Plan Steering Group, Research Projects, Monitoring of effictiveness of conservation measures, raising public awareness are being undertaken.

Corncrake Grant Scheme http://www.npws.ie/farmerslandowners/schemes/corncrakegrantscheme

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info:
There has never been a dedicated national survey on breeding Curlew. Data for 2012 were obtained from asking people to submit what were mostly casual records of Curlew during the breeding season, with follow up surveys where relevant.
The short-term breeding range trend was calculated by comparing the abundance of all 10km square breeding records from the 2007-11 atlas (Balmer et al 2013) along with HELP Project and NPWS unpublished data with those of the 1988-91 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al., 1993). The long-term breeding range trend calculation was based on the 1968-72 breeding atlas (Sharrock 1976) using the same criteria
bird_report.measures_taken: Hunting of Curlew banned (Ob 1). Conservation project & agri-environment schemes (Obs 2 & 3). SPA designation and wildfowl sanctuaries (Obs 5 & 8). Ringing supported (Ob 10).

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources:
The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland (Sharrock 1976) Tucker, G.M. & Heath, M.F. (1994) Birds in Europe: their conservation status. Cambridge, U.K. : BirdLife International (BirdLife Conservation Series No. 3). Summary Results of the Upland Bird Surveys 2002, 2003 & 2004 (Cummins & Newton 2004) - Unpublished BirdWatch Ireland Report.
Partridge JK and Smith KW (1992) Breeding wader populations in Northern Ireland, 1985-1987. Irish Birds 6: 513-526.
Allen, D. & Mellon, C. (unpubl data) cited in 'Bird Habitats in Ireland' 2012, Collins Press, Cork.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: The population trends were calculated after a review of information from a number of sources. The most recent national survey (2002-04) of breeding Golden Plover estimated the population at 134-156 breeding pairs and was based on a survey of all known historic and suitable breeding grounds (see Cummins & Newton 2004). With no more recent national data on numbers of breeding pairs, this 2004 estimate was used to derive short and long-term population trends. Population estimates for breeding Golden Plover pre the Upland Bird Survey of 2002-2004, were given in the breeding bird atlas of 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976), the atlas of 1988-91, (Gibbons et al. 1993) and Birds in Europe I & II. Note, these estimates were largely based on expert opinion. Using the historical estimate of Sharrock (1976) as a baseline for the 1968-1972 breeding population, an approximate estimate for 1980 was derived assuming a constant rate of decline between the estimate for 1972 and 1990 (the latter estimate was taken from Birds in Europe II which utilised all-Ireland figures reported in Gibbons et al. 1993 and taking into account the estimated population in Northern Ireland (Partridge & Smith 1992). The short-term population trend was derived by calculating the percentage change between these estimates (UBS 2002-04) and the minimum figure of 200 breeding pairs reported in Birds In Europe II. (The maximum number of breeding pairs reported in Birds in Europe II (of 400 pairs) was greater than the figure reported in Birds in Europe I (350 pairs). It is very unlikely the population underwent an increase in the intervening years (1990-2000), given the changes in land-use and in habitat extent and quality in the Golden Plover core breeding areas. Hence, the lower figure of 200 pairs detailed in Birds in Europe II was used as the baseline population figure for the year 2000.) Overall, this amounts to a short term population decline between 2000 and 2012 (using the 2004 national population figures from the Upland Bird Surveys as the most recent national total) of some 22-33%. Similar to the short-term trends, the percentage change figure for 1980-2010 is given as a banded figure of 60-75% (more info on the long-term population change figures given below) to reflect the poor quality of the early estimates. Further Information: The long term population trend was calculated as the percentage change in the estimated figure for 1980 and the national Upland Bird Survey 2002-04. The latter estimate is considered to be the most recent and accurate figure on the breeding population. The 1980 figure was derived by firstly estimating the Irish population of breeding Golden Plover from the All-Ireland estimate given by Sharrock (1976) which was based on expert opinion at the time. Using the assumption that the Northern Ireland population (which accounted for 10.5% of the All-Ireland total in the late 1980s) and more recently approx. 10% of all Ireland population (Allen & Mellon unpubl) and was approx. 10.5% of the All-Ireland total (63 pairs) in 1968-72 period, then the Republic of Ireland population was an estimated 537 breeding pairs for the 1968-72 period. A long term population decline was thus calculated by comparing this figure with the first Birds in Europe estimate of 350 pairs (1990) and a population estimate of 454 pairs for 1980 was derived, assuming a constant rate of decline in the population in the intervening period. These long term trend figures were banded (70-75%) to reflect the poorer quality assessment and also reflect the percentage change between the min & max estimates recorded during the Upland Bird Survey 2002-04. As the data provided in the previous atlases (Sharrock 1976; Gibbons et al. 1993) was based on expert opinion, rather than a complete survey, the quality of these trend data (short-term and long-term) is estimated as being poor. *(Note: The Northern Ireland Breeding wader survey 1985-87 with an overall maximum population figure of approx. 50 breeding pairs for Northern Ireland (Partridge & Smith 1992) gives an estimate of 350 breeding pairs for the Republic of Ireland based on the New Atlas totals (Gibbons et al. 93) for the late 1980s to early 1990s and this figure of 350 pairs corresponds to the figure reported in Birds in Europe I.

However, the Bird Atlas 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013), provides a more recent picture of the species distribution in Ireland and therefore data from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 was used to generate the breeding distribution and range maps for the species.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Short term range change was calculated looking at the most recent data availble i.e. The Bird Atlas 2007-11 and the Upland Bird Survey data 2002-04 and these sources of information were used to generate the short-term breeding range trend. Probable & confirmed records were used to calculate percentage change maxima, while probable, confirmed & possible records were used to calculate the percentage change minima. Long term range change was calculated using information from the Bird Atlas 2007-11 and the New Atlas data 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993) using the same criteria. As no information is available on the breeding range for Golden Plover for 1980 it is considered that the breeding range for the New Atlas is the closest representative distribution which was used to generate the long term trend figures.
bird_report.measures_taken: Agri-environmental schemes are in operation in some breeding areas (Ob 2); the overwintering population is monitored by I-WeBS (Obs 8 & 9). Some ringing of Golden Plover occurs (Ob 11); and research into the breeding ecology was also carried out (0b13)

bird_report.population_additional_info: Recent population estimates (Lauder & Donaghy 2008) are approximate and are based on annually reviewed figures from a range of surveys and represent the best assessment of current population levels on machair and bogs from existing available knowledge.

Irish Wildlife Manuals, No.44. National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government, Dublin, Ireland. Lauder, C. & Donaghy, A. (2008) Breeding Waders in Ireland 2008: A review and recommendations for future action. Report to the National Parks & Wildlife Service. Gibbons D.W., Reid J.B. & Chapman R.A. (1993) The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland 1988-1991. Poyser, London. Nairn, R.G.W. & Sheppard, J.R. 1985. Breeding waders of sand dune machair in the north-west Ireland. Irish Birds 1:160-170. Partridge, J.K. 1988 Northern Ireland breeding wader survey. Final Report. RSPB Report to Dept of the Environment (NI) Countryside and Wildlife Branch, Belfast.

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Suddaby, D., Nelson, T. & Veldman, J. (2010) Resurvey of breeding wader populations of machair and associated wet grasslands in north-west Ireland. Irish Wildlife Manuals, No.44. National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government, Dublin, Ireland. Lauder, C. & Donaghy, A. (2008) Breeding Waders in Ireland 2008: A review and recommendations for future action. Report to the National Parks & Wildlife Service.
bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: A national population estimate for 1968-72 was derived using average densities (10-20 pairs per 10km square) for Britain and Ireland cited in Sharrock (1976) which along with the number of occupied 10km squares with confirmed breeding records (N=36). This estimate (360-720 pairs) was then compared with the estimate provided in Lauder & Donaghy (2008) of 150 pairs to derive a long term trend. In the 1988-91 breeding atlas (Gibbons et al. 1993), an All-Ireland estimate of 175 pairs was given which was largely based on overall figures given in a survey of breeding Dunlin on machair in 1985 (Nairn & Shephard 1985) and a survey in Northern Ireland (Partridge 1988). However, the survey of breeding Dunlin in 1985 (Nairn & Shephard 1985) was on machair and did not take into account Dunlin breeding in more upland bog habitats. Hence this estimate was not used to derive a short term population trend. Data available for 35 sites surveyed in each of the breeding machair wader surveys (Suddaby et al. 2010) suggests declines of 57% in the longer term (from 111 pairs in 1985 to 45 pairs in 2009) and a 27% decline in the short term (59 pairs in 1996 to 45 pairs in 2009). If the changes that have occurred on these machair sites (which represent 35% of the national population) are representative of the overall national decline, then using the current national population estimate of 150 pairs, the assumptions are that the breeding Dunlin population was closer to 350 pairs in 1985 and 238 pairs in 1996 giving a short term population decline of 37%. Given the national population estimate for 1996 has been extrapolated from results presented in the machair survey (Suddaby et al. 2010), the trend data have been categorised as poor in quality. Similarly, the long term trend has been categorised as poor in quality as the 1972 estimate was derived from information on average densities provided in the breeding atlas of 1968-72.

British Trust for Ornithology. Sharrock, J.T.R. (1976) The Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland. T. & AD Poyser.
bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Short term range change was calculated looking at the most recent data available, ie. The breeding atlas of 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the breeding atlas of 1988-91 (Gibbons et al. 1993). Differences in the total numbers of records between the two atlases were used to calculate short term trend magnitude figures. The long term breeding range trend was derived using relevant information provided in the breeding atlas of 2007-11 (Balmer et al. 2013) and the breeding atlas of 1968-72 (Sharrock 1976) and was calculated using the same criteria as the short term trend.
